What you need to know You can review a client's approved benefit eligibility and entitlement information to assist when you are making decisions about a client's benefits and when supporting client enquiries. New You can determine eligibility by using the Check Eligibility or Check Potential Eligibility functionality, if required. New Note: If there are any issues with cases involving multiple parties (e.g. client and spouse), please make sure that eligibility checks are performed for both individuals to identify any areas where the eligibility/entitlement rules show up as failed. Eligibility and entitlement information is available in 2 places in Cúram: a graphic view of eligibility information; and a detailed entitlement determination information. Updated The Graph View is accessed from the Integrated Case (i.e. Old Age Security case). It is a high-level graphical view of a client's eligibility and entitlement for an OAS pension, GIS , and ALW and ALWS benefits for a single calendar year. The Graph View displays coloured timelines for each benefit the client has applied for and for which the client satisfies the age requirement. The timelines are labelled with the benefit name and the entitlement amount, or Not Eligible , Not Entitled or Suspended , if applicable. A pop-up window displays eligibility information, such as Rate Table, when you click a timeline interval. Key events in a client's case are indicated on the timeline by a black dot on a month. When you click the black dot, a pop-up window displays that month's events. Possible key events for OAS program benefits include: Application date Requested pension start date 65th birthday 70th birthday 75th birthday 20 years' totalized residence 7th month outside Canada Returned to Canada Incarceration admission date Incarceration release date Special Qualifying Factor anniversary date Living apart for reasons beyond control start date Living apart for reasons beyond control end date Marital status change date Sponsorship start date Sponsorship end date Sponsorship breakdown date Detailed information about determination is also available in the Product Delivery Case (i.e. Old Age Security Benefits case). Available information includes: eligibility and entitlement criteria results; client income information; and the calculations used to determine benefit amounts. New These calculations also provide insight into information, such as Rate Table. You can also view the history of determinations about the client's benefits. Determination information is shown in 4 pages: Table 1—Determinations History tab descriptions Tab Description Summary The Summary tab shows high-level details about a client's: Entitlement Amount Eligibility Entitlement Eligibility Criteria The Eligibility Criteria tab shows the criteria used to determine the client's eligibility. This includes: Application Details Age Legal Status OAS Historical / Initial Residency GIS Initial Residency GIS Ongoing Residency OAS Pension Status for GIS Entitlement Criteria The Entitlement Criteria tab shows the criteria used to determine the client’s entitlement. This includes: Deferral Sponsorship Status Incarceration Status Country of Residence and Portability New Spouse/Partner GIS Entitlement Requirement Income The Income tab details information about the client’s income and the client’s spouse’s income. Note: The Income tab appears only if the client receives the GIS or the ALW or ALWS benefits. Calculations The Calculations tab includes 2 sections in the group navigation bar (OAS and GIS ). It shows details about a client’s entitlement amount calculation, including the Calculation Used , and any alternate calculations and entitlement overrides. What you need to know You can create an ALW and ALWS application from a person's record or prospect person's record. You can add an ALW and ALWS application form with the information found in the Application for the Allowance or Allowance for the Survivor - Under the Old Age Security Program (ISP-3008) or the Application for Allowance Under the Old Age Security Program (ISP-3033) form provided by the client. After you submit the application form, an Application Case will automatically be created under the Cases and Applications tab. Refer to OAS/GIS Application Case—View, Authorize, Reopen and Print in Cúram (Action) . In order to send correspondence to the client to request missing information, in cases of incomplete applications, the application must be added in Curam to create an Application Case. It is necessary to capture consent for the spouse in the Application Case. If consent has already been provided in a previous application, this can be referenced from past data. If no prior consent exists, new consent must be obtained. The Consent and Declaration evidence captures this information and can be found on the Evidence Dashboard of the Application Case. The full period of the marital relationship must be entered to determine entitlement for ALW or ALWS . When a spouse’s date of death is added to the ALW or ALWS Application Case , the  applicant’s Marital Status evidence is set to Survivor when the application is submitted. Note: When a date of death is entered in Cúram either manually or from the CRA, a task is generated to reconcile this evidence with all cases and applications to which the deceased individual might be party. If the spouse has been deceased for 12 months or more from the application Receipt Date , and a Marital Relationship evidence issue is created, you can delete the evidence and proceed with processing the application. If the spouse’s death date is less than 12 months from the application receipt date, the spouse must remain on the application case with complete marital relationship details, income information, and date of death. Complete a manual check of eligibility before authorizing ALW or ALWS benefits to see the potential outcome of authorization. This creates a potential eligibility check on the Application Case with a detailed summary of all criteria assessed to determine eligibility. The evidence dashboard of the application case will indicate any evidence that needs to be verified before authorization can occur, including marital status. H2 Exp-coll: Incorrect end date on Marital relationship If the system is not accurately End Dating the Marital Relationship when the OAS Recipient died and identifying that the ALW applicant is a Surviving Spouse (Widow/ widower) or Surviving Common- Law Partner then follow the steps below. In Cúram, go to the Person profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Navigate to the Cases and Applications tab and then to the Applications inline tab. Click the Reference Number for the ALW application. Application case will open in a new tab. Navigate to the Marital Relationship evidence on the ALW Application Case (click the Evidence tab on the Application Case). Select to Edit the Marital Relationship evidence (ensure that the OAS/GIS Recipient is added as the Related participant for the ALW applicant, if the OAS/GIS recipient is not added by the system. Refer steps below for reference). Enter the “Effective Date of Change” as the Date of Death of the OAS/GIs recipient AND choose the Relationship Status as “Surviving spouse (Widow/ widower) or Surviving Common- Law Partner”. Save the Marital Relationship evidence. Apply Changes to the Marital Relationship evidence. Ensure there are no Mandatory Tasks open or Verifications pending. Perform a Check Eligibility to ensure that the system is displaying the ALW applicant as eligible. Navigate to the Benefits tab on the Application Case to Authorize the ALWS benefit. Note: Users can navigate to Tasks tab on the Application Case to view, if there are any mandatory tasks open. To review any pending verification, Users can navigate to the Evidence -&gt; Verification on the Application Case. H2 Exp-coll: Adding a related participant If Agent has to add a related participant, please follow the steps below. In Cúram, go to the Person profile of the Spouse. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Navigate to the Current Cases section. Click the Reference Number for the Type Old Age Security. OAS Integrated Case will open in a new tab. Click the Evidence tab. Navigate to the Marital Relationship evidence and select the ‘New Case Member Search’. The Person Search window appears. Enter the First Name and Last Name of the OAS Recipient. Click the Search button. Choose the Select hyperlink under the Action column header in the Search results. Enter the Relationship Details (Married/ Common-Law) and Start Date . Click Save . Apply Changes to the evidence. Ensure that there is no pending tasks or verification for the evidence. H2 Exp-coll: Deceased spouse was never in our System Please follow the steps below for a Deceased Spouse ( ALWS ), where the OAS Recipient (deceased spouse) was never in the system before. Delete the Marital Relationship evidence from the ALWS Application Case. Navigate to the Cases and Applications tab and then select Applications page group navigation bar. Click on the Reference link to the Application. Application case will open in new tab. Click the Evidence tab. Select/ click the Marital Relationship evidence. The Marital Relationship evidence will open in new tab. Click the ( &gt; ) toggle icon. Click the 3-dots ( ... ) action menu and select to Delete the evidence. Apply Changes to the evidence from the Evidence Dashboard . Ensure the Marital Status (at Person level ) for the ALWS applicant is appropriate. Note: Marital Status should be "Surviving spouse (Widow/ widower) or Surviving Common- Law Partner” (If the marital status is not reflecting the status of survivor, then update using the appropriate date). Navigate to the evidence dashboard and select the Manually Entered Income evidence to enter the income for the Applicant. Perform a Check Eligibility to ensure that ALWS applicant is found to be eligible for ALWS . Note: Please navigate to the Potential Eligibility tab on the Application Case, then click Check Eligibility link to perform a check eligibility. Authorize the Application. Note: Navigate to the Benefit tab on the Application Case, then select the 3-dots ( ... ) action menu and choose the option to Authorize, to Authorize the application. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05446&amp;cid=CAT-02016</reference><title>Manage Duplicate Person Records in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>['https://014gc.sharepoint.com/sites/95530/Howto%20Clips/How-to%20Clips/Processing/Processors/Managing%20Person%20Profiles/View%20and%20Merge%20Person%20Duplicates.mp4']</video_link><video_name>['View and Merge Person Duplicates']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with the steps to follow to manage duplicate person records in Cúram. What you need to know Each person in Cúram should have only one record. If a duplicate record is created, (e.g. when a client's name is changed and a person search does not find a match), the duplicate record must be resolved. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Duplicate records must be merged into a single master record for that person so that the master record can be a single source of reliable data on that person. It is important to note that merging records is a manual function and must not be used frequently. Marking a person record as duplicate You must mark a record as a duplicate before you can merge records. Before marking a record as a duplicate, you must decide which of the records is the master and which is the secondary. To determine which person record should be the master, consider the following: which account has the most amount of accurate information. if one record has a permanent SIN (100-899 series) and the other does not: Person merge is not allowed when the master record has a temporary SIN and duplicate person record has a non-SIN Identifier or no SIN. In this case, by making the non-SIN identifier or no SIN the master, you will be able to perform the merge using the Merge Person wizard. Person merge is not allowed when both the master and duplicate records have a temporary SIN. In this case, you will not be able to use the Merge Person wizard. However, you can still mark one of the records as a duplicate using the steps outlined in the What You Need to do section. You can then manually recreate the evidence on the master record. if either profile has any applications: If neither profile has any applications, the profile with the earliest record should be the master record. If one profile has applications and the other does not, the profile with applications should be the master record. if both profiles have applications, the profile with the earliest record should be the master record. if there are two records where one is a registered person and the other is a prospect person, the record where one is a registered person must always be the master record. A prospect record cannot be a master record. If 2 prospect records need to be merged, you need to decide which will be the master record and upgrade it to a registered person first. Refer to Register a Prospect Person as a Person in Cúram (Action) . the information on ITRDS . Once you have identified the master and the secondary records, you must do the following, as applicable: Close all open tasks on the duplicate record before starting the merge process. Confirm that the evidence periods of the records do not overlap. If there is an overlap, update the evidence on the master profile and then create any manual overpayments. Any underpayments will be issued by Cúram. If updated evidences result in any payment corrections, Cúram will automatically create the payment corrections as underpayment or overpayment. However, Cúram will not recognize entitlement that was already paid on the duplicate record so any monetary that is calculated may need to be offset towards the overpayment to bring the account into balance. Refer to Liability Offset—Create, Complete and Delete in Cúram (Action) . If there are any applications on the duplicate record, you must recreate them on the master record. Take screenshots of the evidence and case information from the duplicate record and upload the screenshots as attachment in the master record. If these records need to be unmerged later due to an error, the screenshots will assist in re-creating the evidence and case information on the duplicate record. Refer to Attachments—Add, View, Modify, Delete, Move and Search in Cúram (Action) . Once the record is marked as a duplicate, you use a wizard to merge the records' person level evidence. If there are any application cases on the duplicate record, you must manually recreate them on the master record. Both person records remain visible, but one is marked as a duplicate in the context panel. You will be able to toggle to a duplicate record via the master record by clicking on the Administration tab, but you will not be able to do the same on the duplicate record. In addition, the search results will also identify a duplicate record via a duplicate icon. The duplicate person record will no longer be used in case processing, and you cannot make changes to it. The cases on the duplicate record will still exist, however, the cases will be in a view only mode and the following message will display on the Home page: "This case belongs to a duplicate person. Do not perform any updates on this case." Cúram will display a comment to indicate that a merge was performed for any person level evidence that were merged through the wizard. All communication and attachments will be copied over to the master record. Note: During merging, most of the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) marital status, CRA birth and death details and CRA lifetime list evidence cannot be merged to the master person record since they are read-only fields. Unmarking a person record marked as duplicate in error If a record was marked as a duplicate in error, you can unmark it. This will unmerge the records if they have been previously merged and it can be used in case processing again. The record will no longer be marked as a duplicate. Unmarking does not remove any of the merged data that was copied into the original record if a merge was already performed. You must manually delete any evidence brought over from the secondary account and close any cases. You may also have to re-adjust the financials, amend tax slips, etc., depending on the situation. Cúram will add a comment to the evidence to indicate that the evidence record is from a duplicate account. Guidelines for Determining the Master Record Use the following guidelines to determine which record should be considered the master record: Table 1—Guidelines for Determining the Master Record Situation Action Person A has one or multiple Foreign Engagement Cases (FEC). Person B has one or multiple Application Case (OAS/ GIS / ALW / ALWS ) that has not been authorized (not withdrawn, denied, closed, or approved). Identify Master record. Master: Person A–FEC exists. Merge Person B into Person A. Note: Ultimately, this is a judgement call by the Employment and Social Development Canada representative as there could be other hinderances (e.g. a temporary SIN that may need to be taken into consideration). Add the proper Application Case to the master person record. Refer to the following procedures: Add an OAS and GIS Application Form in Cúram (Action) Add an ALW or ALWS Application Form in Cúram (Action) Person A has one or multiple FECs. Person B has one or more Application Cases (OAS/ GIS / ALW / ALWS ) where one has been authorized. Identify Master record. Master: Person B–OAS authorized Merge Person A into Person B. Recreate the FECs in the master person record. Refer to the following procedures: Foreign Engagement Case—Add, View, Edit and Close in Cúram (Action) Foreign Application—Add, Access, Modify, and Delete in Cúram (Action) Foreign Creditable Period—Add, View, Edit or Delete in Cúram (Action) Liaison—Add, Modify, Access and Delete in Cúram (Action) Residence Period—Add, View and Edit in Cúram (Action) Person A has OAS pension in pay. Person B has OAS pension in pay. This also applies if both persons are both receiving OAS and GIS . Identify the Master record. The master record is the one with the earliest effective date. Create or update any applicable case-level evidences on the master person record (this includes FECs). Review the past payments in the duplicate person record and manually calculate the overpayment amount, if applicable. This must include all money that was paid on the duplicate record that Cúram will calculate underpayments for on the master record. Create the overpayment in the master person record. Refer to Overpayment (Manual) Case—Add, View, Edit, Suspend and Delete in Cúram (Action) . Apply any underpayments or arrears payments calculated by the updated evidences to the overpayment using a void offset resulting in a debt adjustment not collection. Refer to Liability Offset—Create, Complete and Delete in Cúram (Action) . Note: If the underpayments or arrears payments are not overlapping with the period paid on the duplicate, they must be applied as a non-void offset to be treated as monies collected towards the debt. Recreate any other liabilities (i.e. existing departmental liabilities, cross program recoveries, Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) set offs, etc.) on the master record. Refer to Overpayment (Manual) Case—Add, View, Edit, Suspend and Delete in Cúram (Action) . Refer to Liability Allocation—View, Create, Deactivate, Reactivate and Delete in Cúram (Action) . Note: If updated evidences result in any payment corrections, Cúram will automatically create the payment corrections as underpayment or overpayment. However, Cúram will not recognize entitlement that was already paid on the duplicate record so any monetary that is calculated may need to be offset towards the overpayment to bring the account into balance. If the OAS benefit is not approved, the first entry into Canada details evidence is maintained in the Application Case. If the benefit is authorized and approved, the first entry into Canada details evidence is maintained in the Integrated Case. What you need to know After a task is created by Cúram, it is automatically allocated to a work queue where it can be reserved to a user if: the user has the required skills to complete the new task. OR the user has one or more reserved tasks for the same client; and the user has the required skills to complete the new task. Note: Manually created tasks are not automatically allocated. Note: Integrity-related tasks are not automatically allocated. The Integrity Services Branch (ISB) tasks will be manually allocated through the ISB region's workload distribution team. You can use the Get Next Task... function to add tasks to your Open Tasks list from your Inbox or from a Manual Work Queue: From the Inbox If you are usually assigned work through automatic allocation and have no open tasks assigned, you can contact the team lead to assign more work or use the Get Next Task... function from your Inbox. Cúram will prioritize the tasks in the automatic work queue that correspond to your region and reserve the next priority task that matches your location, language, and skill type. Tasks are prioritized as High, Medium and Low and sorted within the priority group as follows: Receipt Date (oldest to newest) Creation Date (oldest to newest) Due Date (oldest to newest) If more than one automated work queue is applicable, Cúram sorts across all applicable automated work queues as one. Note: You will not receive tasks through automatic allocation if you do not have your skills set up. From a Manual Work Queue If you are usually required to add tasks to your Open Tasks list from a manual work queue, you can use Get Next Task… from the selected manual work queue to prompt Cúram to allocate the next priority task. Cúram will prioritize the tasks in the manual work queue that match your language and reserve the most prioritized task. Note: The Get Next Task... from a manual work queue is to be generally used when working on manual workload or campaign queues and you must be subscribed to the manual work queue by your team lead. Tasks are grouped by High, Medium and Low priority and sorted within the priority group as follows: Receipt Date (oldest to newest) Creation Date (oldest to newest) Due Date (oldest to newest) Note: When a Mailroom Clerk receives a new document for upload, Cúram will create a new task which will go to the allocation batch. If the new task's Skill Type matches the Skill Type of the officer allocated to another task for the same client, Cúram will bundle the tasks to the officer. Note: If you are usually assigned work through automatic allocation, you need to be aware that there is a Maximum Task Threshold rule applied in Curam. This means that if your Open Tasks reach the max task threshold of 30 tasks, the batch run will no longer seek to reserve tasks for you. When the automatic allocation batch has assigned a task to a user, it will scan the remaining unreserved tasks for the same client to see which can be bundled to the same user provided they have the skillset to complete the task. Bundling rules do not validate against the max task threshold (30 tasks), meaning that a user can still receive a task via bundling if they are at their max task limit (30 tasks). The Get Next Task window opens. Click Yes . Cúram adds the selected task to your Open Tasks list to reserve it. Note: Cúram identifies the task that can be reserved to you based on the matches to your skills type, language and region. What you need to know A person's residential and/or mailing address needs to be captured upon registration. Once on file, the address can be viewed, edited, or removed. An address must always remain on a Person or Prospect Person's profile. Mailing and residential addresses can be adjusted separately. If a client wants to add a new mailing address only, the residential address can remain as is. Current mailing addresses are mandatory in Cúram. However, future dated addresses can be edited. When editing current addresses, Cúram will require activation to make the address effective, but activation is not required upon registration. Once you save a new address, Cúram automatically assigns an end date to the old address. The end date of an old address in Cúram cannot overlap with the start date of a new address. When receiving an address change request, use the current date as the start date, not the date of receipt (if earlier). Note: Cúram allows for diverse ways of adding or editing addresses. This article focuses on one of the possible ways. Post Office box used as residential address When updating or capturing an address, start by searching with the postal code provided by the client. The system will display the results. If a client or applicant provides a PO Box address as their home address, you must request confirmation of their address their civic address or physical location. Refer to Post Office Boxes (Action) . Once the confirmation has been received, instead of selecting one of the search results after entering the postal code, click on Add New Address . This will display a second page where you can capture the address manually in the below format: Example Civic Number: LOT 40 Street Name: Concession 1 City, Town, or Village: Bight Province, Territory, State or Region: Newfoundland Postal Code: A0E1B0 For clients using a Postal Office box as their residential address in the United States, you may capture the Postal Office box as a residential address too. For clients living in countries outside of Canada and the United States, addresses will be captured as Address Line 1, Address Line 2, and Address Line 3, with PO box addresses being captured under Address Line 1. Address guidelines To reduce the cost and the volume of returned correspondence for CPP and OAS operations, it is important that you review and record and/or enter the person's address accurately. The most common error in address formatting is the apartment or suite number. The correct format for a Canadian address with an apartment or suite number requires it to appear before the civic address number, with a hyphen in between, without spaces and without the word "suite" or the "#" symbol. New Note: You must not enter “C/O” in the Unit/Apt/Suite Number field when adding or updating an address, as this will cause an error in the Public Sector Collections and Disbursements system. The Third Party Contact evidence has a field which allows you to select who receives correspondence for the client (i.e. Client Only , Client and Third Party , or Third Party ). Based on your selection, the name of the Third Party will appear in the Create Correspondence field when correspondence is sent. Table 1—Correct and Incorrect Address Comparison Incorrect Correct 401 70 ROYAL OAK PLAZA NW 401-70 ROYAL OAK PLAZA NW 7 — 2019 TRAWLEN WAY 7-2019 TRAWLEN WAY 805 CONCESSION ST NO 2 2-805 CONCESSION ST SUITE 5, 302 NORTH RIVER ROAD 5-302 NORTH RIVER RD SUITE 5 302 NORTH RIVER ROAD 5-302 NORTH RIVER RD #3, 245 MONTREAL ROAD 3-245 MONTREAL RD Note: When entering an address located in Canada or the United States, a distinct line is available to indicate the Unit/Apt/Suite Number. In that case, do not enter the apartment or suite number before the civic address with a hyphen. Enter them separately within their distinct fields. Refer to the guidelines listed in Edit a person's address in the What you need to do section of the Step by Step tab . What you need to know A sponsored immigrant is an individual who has been admitted to Canada as a permanent resident under a sponsorship agreement. Sponsorship evidence uses Yes/No to record whether a client entered Canada under a sponsorship agreement. This evidence is not read by Eligibility and Entitlement rules. Additional related evidence (Sponsorship Agreement) is used to record the details of the sponsorship period. This is the evidence used by the Eligibility and Entitlement rules. The evidences exist in both Application Cases and Integrated Cases. If the pension or benefit is not approved, the sponsorship evidences are maintained in the Application Case. If the benefit is authorized and approved, the sponsorship evidences are maintained in the Integrated Case. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05452&amp;cid=CAT-02017</reference><title>Non-Residential Tax Withhold—View and Edit in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with steps to view and edit a non-resident tax withhold deduction in Cúram. What you need to know Non-resident tax is a deduction in Cúram and is applied to OAS benefits. The non-resident tax default varies between 10% and 25% of the OAS benefits, depending on whether there is a tax treaty with the applicable country in place or in cases where there is an approved request for a non-resident tax reduction. Note: The country in which a client resides determines whether the non-resident tax is applicable or not. A non-resident tax withhold deduction is automatically created when an OAS benefits product delivery case is created for a client whose current and/or future residential address is not within Canada, United States or the United Kingdom. Note: A non-resident tax withhold deduction will not be created against a foreign residential address evidence in a person evidence case that is end-dated before the benefit starts. Cúram automatically creates or updates the deduction based on trigger events. The default non-resident tax withhold deduction will be configured as a third-party variable deduction on the OAS product delivery case. The residential address evidence or the non-residential tax correction evidence provides the start date, end date and percentage of the non-resident tax withhold deduction. The trigger events that update the non-resident tax withhold deduction are: Table 1—Trigger events that update the non-resident tax withhold deductions, event and description Trigger event Description Deemed non-resident Non-resident clients can request a reduction in the amount of non-resident tax required to be withheld from the CRA . On approval of the request, the CRA informs the Department of the non-resident tax rate reduction. Deemed resident A deemed resident is not subjected to the non-resident tax. The CRA identifies deemed residents each year and sends a list of these clients to the Department. Retroactive recovery of the non-resident tax (current year only) This is required in situations where: The client's foreign residential address is entered retroactively. Past payments are already processed. The agent determines that a higher non-resident tax deduction rate is required for this client to recover what was previously not deducted. The CRA requests an increase of the rate of the non-resident tax withhold of a specific client. Such an increase may occur because the CRA has received additional income information following an original decision to reduce the withhold rate. Note: The non-resident tax evidence manages the non-resident tax correction scenarios. Tax treaty non-resident tax rate change In the event of the change in the non-resident tax rate, Cúram sets the end date for the current non-resident tax and creates new non-resident tax withhold deductions through a batch process. The batch is manually triggered to create or update deductions. Once the batch is run, Cúram updates the existing non-resident tax withhold deduction based on the values provided in the evidence. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: View a non-residential tax correction In Cúram, go to the person's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Cases and Applications tab. Click Cases in the page group navigation bar on the left. The list of available cases appears. Click the hyperlink for the Old Age Security Program Benefit case in the Reference column. The case opens in a new tab. Click the Financials tab. Click Deductions in the page group navigation bar on the left. The list of available Non-Resident Tax deductions appears. H2 Exp-coll: Manual adjustment of a non-residential tax correction In Cúram, go to the person's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Cases and Applications tab. Click Cases in the page group navigation bar on the left. The list of available Cases will appear. Click the hyperlink for the Old Age Security case. The case opens in a new tab. Click the Evidence tab. Click Non-Resident Tax Correction in the Deduction section of the Evidence Dashboard. Click the ( &gt; ) toggle icon to show the evidence. Click Edit . The Edit Non-Resident Tax Correction window opens. Enter the following details in the Edit Non-Resident Tax Correction window: Table 2—Fields and directions under Edit Non-Resident Tax Correction window Field Direction Date Received Mandatory Verify the date under Date Received . If the date is correct, leave the field as is. If the date is incorrect, select the correct date from the calendar. Change Reason Mandatory Select a reason from the Change Reason drop-down menu. Participant This field cannot be edited. The information displayed is obtained from the Integrated Case. Correction Reason This field cannot be edited. The information displayed is obtained from the Integrated Case. Country This field cannot be edited. The information displayed is obtained from the Integrated Case. Percentage Enter the recovery percentage. Note: A blank value in the percentage field will default to 0%. Start Date Mandatory Verify the date under Start Date . If the date is correct, leave the field as is. If the date is incorrect, select the correct date from the calendar. End Date Mandatory Verify the date under End Date . If the date is correct, leave the field as is. If the date is incorrect, select the correct date from the calendar. Enter the comments in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Save . What you need to know Non-resident tax is a deduction in Cúram and is applied to OAS benefits. The non-resident tax default varies between 10% and 25% of the OAS benefits, depending on whether there is a tax treaty with the applicable country in place or in cases where there is an approved request for a non-resident tax reduction. Note: The country in which a client resides determines whether the non-resident tax is applicable or not. A non-resident tax withhold deduction is automatically created when an OAS benefits product delivery case is created for a client whose current and/or future residential address is not within Canada, United States or the United Kingdom. Note: A non-resident tax withhold deduction will not be created against a foreign residential address evidence in a person evidence case that is end-dated before the benefit starts. Cúram automatically creates or updates the deduction based on trigger events. The default non-resident tax withhold deduction will be configured as a third-party variable deduction on the OAS product delivery case. The residential address evidence or the non-residential tax correction evidence provides the start date, end date and percentage of the non-resident tax withhold deduction. The trigger events that update the non-resident tax withhold deduction are: Table 1—Trigger events that update the non-resident tax withhold deductions, event and description Trigger event Description Deemed non-resident Non-resident clients can request a reduction in the amount of non-resident tax required to be withheld from the CRA . On approval of the request, the CRA informs the Department of the non-resident tax rate reduction. Deemed resident A deemed resident is not subjected to the non-resident tax. The CRA identifies deemed residents each year and sends a list of these clients to the Department. Retroactive recovery of the non-resident tax (current year only) This is required in situations where: The client's foreign residential address is entered retroactively. Past payments are already processed. The agent determines that a higher non-resident tax deduction rate is required for this client to recover what was previously not deducted. The CRA requests an increase of the rate of the non-resident tax withhold of a specific client. Such an increase may occur because the CRA has received additional income information following an original decision to reduce the withhold rate. Note: The non-resident tax evidence manages the non-resident tax correction scenarios. Tax treaty non-resident tax rate change In the event of the change in the non-resident tax rate, Cúram sets the end date for the current non-resident tax and creates new non-resident tax withhold deductions through a batch process. The batch is manually triggered to create or update deductions. Once the batch is run, Cúram updates the existing non-resident tax withhold deduction based on the values provided in the evidence. What you need to know The OAS recovery tax is a tax on higher-income OAS pensioners whose individual net income, for a given base taxation year, is above the threshold determined by the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA). It is applicable for both Canadian residents and non-residents. The CRA will send the information regarding the OAS Recovery Tax Deduction through an established interface or through other non-interface channels, like paper communication. Note: The CRA is the only trusted source for the OAS recovery tax information. The OAS recovery tax evidence in Cúram is added on Integrated Case and used to record the OAS recovery tax information received from the CRA. Once it is activated, Cúram uses this evidence to create the OAS Recovery Tax Deduction on the client's payment and/or benefit. Note: OAS recovery tax evidence should only be added and edited when you are instructed by the CRA. Note: Changes cannot be made to the CRA deduction record directly. The OAS recovery tax evidence can be deleted if the deduction has not been included in the financial payment issuance run. If the OAS recovery tax evidence is deleted, the associated deduction record will also be deleted. Note: Only use the Delete function in exceptional circumstances (e.g. when the information was recorded on an incorrect client account). Generally, Edit function is used to manage the existing evidence. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: Add OAS recovery tax evidence In Cúram, go to the client's profile. Note: You must always capture the enquiry on an Integrated Case when one exists. Otherwise, capture the enquiry on the person record. What you need to know Note: Although capturing an enquiry at the processing centre might be rare, there are certain circumstances where processing Users will need to capture enquiries such as the Regional Enquiry Unit that will capture client interactions (i.e. enquiries from Ministers, Member of Parliament (MP)s or ones identified as Dire Need). When a new enquiry is received, it is captured in Cúram. All incoming enquiries must be captured on the appropriate case (i.e. Person profile, Prospect Person profile, Application Case, Integrated case, Reconsideration Case, Overpayment Case, Product Delivery Case or Foreign Engagement Case). If a Person record does not exist, you must create one along with the relevant case and then capture the incoming enquiry. Refer to Register a Person in Cúram (Action) . If the enquiry is from a third party, you must confirm that it has been verified by accessing the third party evidence. Refer to Third Party Contacts—Add, View, Edit, and Delete in Cúram (Action) . An enquiry can be identified as urgent by checking the Urgent box. When the Urgent box is checked, the associated task is marked Urgent , the escalation level is set, and the task priority is set to Medium . Only the following enquiry types can be marked Urgent : Enquiry – Address Change Enquiry – Death Notification Enquiry – Foreign Direct Deposit Enquiry – Letters &amp; Documentation Enquiry – Payment Related Enquiry – Processing Status Enquiry – T4 Related Enquiry – Interim Application for Foreign Benefits Request Enquiry – US Application Enquiry – Integrity Investigation Follow-up Enquiry – Other Enquiry – Foreign Benefits Enquiry – Canadian Benefits Income – GIS Renewal Telecentre Contact Report (3088) Privacy Request – Tier 1 Privacy Request – Tier 2 REU – Member of Parliament REU – Ministerial REU – Office for Client Satisfaction REU – Third Party Organization If the enquiry type is Enquiry – Dire needs , MP Enquiry or Ministerial Enquiry , the system automatically : escalates the enquiry; sets the priority of associated tasks to High ; and and adds an Urgent flag Note: Members of Parliament and Ministerial offices are considered a high priority, and enquiries from these must receive a reply within 48 hours of receipt. When updating an existing enquiry, use the Edit function to correct previously captured data. A new record is not created. To create a follow-up record for an enquiry of the same type (e.g. when you need to escalate the existing enquiry to a second level and beyond), you must click New… on the appropriate communication record rather than clicking Create Communication . This is to avoid mistakenly selecting a different type when creating a follow-up to an existing enquiry. What you need to know Overpayments made to a client receiving an OAS pension or benefits are processed as liabilities against the client and are considered debts that must be repaid. An investigation by ISB may determine that an overpayment assigned to a client is a result of a misrepresentation or fraud by a third party. In this case the person who committed the fraud or misrepresentation is liable for the debt, not the client. When a notification of misrepresentation or fraud is received, you must reallocate the overpayment to the account of the person who committed the fraud or misrepresentation and write-off (i.e. reduce) the overpayment on the original client's account in Cúram. What you need to know The Pension Trusted Digital Repository (PTDR) is the document repository system where documents are saved. When the mailroom receives documents, the Mailroom clerk will upload the documents in the PTDR. Once the documents are saved in the PTDR, the repository will send the information to Cúram. Cúram will run batch process to retrieve the documents scanned to the PTDR and upload the documents as attachments in Cúram under the Contacts tab in the person profile. Cúram will create a task for the mailroom clerk. At first, the documents in the Attachments page under the Contacts tab only display Other as the document type. The mailroom clerk will triage the documents and update the type of the document appropriately. Subsequently, Cúram will generate a task for Processing to review the attachments and move the attachments to the correct place (e.g. a specific case, verification and appeal). Cúram stores attachments in various places, including: Person/prospect profile External party Foreign Engagement Case Application Case Product Delivery Case Integrated Case Overpayment case Underpayment case Verifications Appeals When required, you can also manually add an attachment to a person, prospect person, external party, verification and all cases. When a document is uploaded into Cúram, the document will be sent to PTDR for storage and an attachment is created to represent the document in Cúram. The attachment links to the document in PTDR so that it can be viewed if needed. However, attachments added to Cúram (without a document uploaded) will not be transmitted to the PTDR as records. New Note: Attachments cannot exceed 10MB in size. If the size exceeds the allowed limit, multiple attachments of 10 MB or less will need to be added. What you need to know Cúram creates an overpayment case when an individual has received more OAS benefits than they were entitled to. Staff members can also manually create overpayments. There are 2 types of overpayment cases in Cúram: Table 1—Types and Descriptions of Cúram overpayment cases Type Description Benefit Overpayment cases A Benefit Overpayment case is created automatically when a recalculation is completed on previously-paid benefits in Cúram. Manual overpayment Manual overpayment cases are created by staff members. Refer to Overpayment (Manual) Case—Add, View, Edit, Suspend and Delete in Cúram (Action) . After each recalculation of a client's eligibility and entitlement, Cúram creates a Benefit Overpayment case if the benefits the client received at a given time were determined to be too high. The case created in this way covers all OAS pension or benefit types that a client has that have been affected by that recalculation. For example, if the client has both the OAS pension and the GIS , and both are overpaid, then one Benefit Overpayment case will be created to combine both debts. Each debt will appear as a separate line item. If the same client is determined to be overpaid after a future recalculation of eligibility and entitlements, then another Benefit Overpayment case will be created. Separate Benefit Overpayment cases will be created if the client is overpaid different benefits (such as OAS and GIS ) for different periods. You can suspend and unsuspend Benefit Overpayment cases. When a case is suspended, any related deduction will be deactivated, and the max deduction amount will be recalculated. When a suspended Benefit Overpayment case is unsuspended, Cúram recalculates the max deduction amount and reactivates any applicable deduction. Migration of overpayment cases will not be combined with Payment corrections. You must continue to follow previous guidance for overpayment recovery, especially for cases involving deceased clients. Benefit Overpayment cases contain the following tabs: Table 2—Tab Names and Details in a Benefit Overpayment Case Tab Name Detail Home The Home tab consists of 3 sections: Case Details Comments Recent Transactions The Case Details section provides a summary of the client, benefits, owner, certification frequency, status, overpayment reason, maximum deduction amount, fraud or misrepresentation, billing pattern and creation date. The Comments section displays any comments entered in this case. The Recent Transactions section documents all the actions that were taken on this case. Tasks The Tasks tab displays the tasks related to the Benefit Overpayment case. Contacts The Contacts tab consists of the following pages: Communications Attachments The Communications page contains recorded enquiries and letters sent to the clients related to the Benefit Overpayment case. The Attachments page contains all the links to the documentation stored in the Pension Trusted Digital Repository (e.g. application, supporting documents) associated with the Benefit Overpayment case. Financials The Financials tab consists of the following pages: Transactions Deductions The Transactions page lists the information of liabilities, cash receipts and benefit deduction made on the Benefit Overpayment case. The Deductions page lists deductions applied against the client's benefits to settle the overpayment. Participants The Participants tab displays the information of all parties to the Benefit Overpayment case. This includes their name, type, as well as the start date and end date for their involvement in the case. Administration The Administration tab consists of the following pages: Transaction History Status History Related Cases User Roles The Transaction History page documents all the detailed actions that were taken in the Benefit Overpayment case. The Status History page documents all updates to the status of the Benefit Overpayment case. The Related Cases page lists the product delivery case associated with the Benefit Overpayment case. The User Roles page lists the case owner and case supervisor assigned to the Benefit Overpayment case. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05461&amp;cid=CAT-02019</reference><title>Liability Offset—Create, Complete and Delete in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with the steps to create, complete and delete a liability offset in Cúram. What you need to know Updated When a client has an overpayment or liability related to OAS (e.g. an interest or penalty debt), it is important to prioritize reducing the outstanding balance for these debts using any underpayment or arrears owing to the client. Only after this reduction should the remaining underpayment or arrears funds be paid to the client. New The following tasks are automatically generated to identify opportunities to reduce an overpayment by applying an underpayment or arrears: Table 1. Automatically generated tasks and description Task Description New Underpayment activation New This task is triggered when an underpayment is created and there is an existing overpayment. New Overpayment activation New This task is triggered when an overpayment is created and there is an existing underpayment. Updated The Liability Offset section of the Financials tab of the Person's record displays records for liability offsets related to underpayment and arrears components of each benefit type in a product delivery case. Each record has 3 action items: Approve ; Complete ; and Delete . Updated The Liability Offset wizard is the mechanism used to apply any underpayment or retroactive amounts to reduce the outstanding amount of departmental overpayments (e.g. penalty, interest, manual overpayment, payment correction-overpaid liabilities). It allows you to enter an offset amount that will be deducted from the liability. Updated The first page of the Liability Offset wizard is used to input offset details. You must input the approved offset amount, which represents the maximum amount of the underpayment that can be applied to the overpayment. New You can apply one underpayment or arrears owing to a client to multiple overpayments and they can be void and non-void, as required. Updated The second page of the Liability Offset wizard is used to specify the offset amount to be applied to each departmental overpayment (e.g. penalty, interest, manual overpayment, payment correction-overpaid liabilities), as applicable. You cannot enter an offset amount that exceeds the outstanding amount of the liability. Additionally, you cannot enter a total offset amount that exceeds the outstanding amount of the offset entered on the first page of the Liability Offset wizard. Clicking Save on this page creates a Liability Offset Item. New Note: When you apply one underpayment or arrears to multiple overpayments, you must create a separate offset for each overpayment. Do not complete the offset until you have finished creating all offsets. Void offset New A void offset is used to fix financial errors caused by mistakes when entering and applying evidence, or for internal balancing. Void offsets do not appear on client records or tax slips. Instead of deductions, they are reported to the Public Sector Collections and Disbursements (PSCD) system as debt adjustments and reduces the overpayment amount that was originally sent. They must match the benefit type and coverage period. The void offset is found in the Liability Offset wizard. You can also check the Void Offset box for Underpayment Liability Offset records. In cases where a Payment Correction-Overpaid case is created due to an error and an underpayment is generated after correcting the error, you can offset the underpayment using the Payment Correction-Overpaid liability and check the Void Offset box. This creates a liability offset item to void the mistakenly generated underpayment amount. If the Void Offset box is checked, you can only offset Payment Correction-Overpaid and Manual Overpayment liabilities for the Underpayment Liability Offset for the same coverage period. Non-void offset New Non-void offset (i.e. when the Void Offset box is not checked) is treated as a recovery and recorded as payment toward the overpayment. The non-void offset transaction will: be reported to the Public Sector Collections and Disbursements system; affect Year to Date and gross pension amounts; impact the tax slips; and be recorded as a recovered overpayment amount. Note: Encoding a write-off reallocation to remove these impacts on the tax slips will not completely resolve the issues. Any balances from the non-void offset will appear in automatically generated letters and letters created manually in the Corporate Correspondence Tool. If you encounter a situation where you need to check the Void Offset box and it is greyed it out, you must submit a National Service Desk Internal link technical ticket. No further actions should be taken until this ticket is resolved. Note: For the renewal of benefits, the recovery from arrears must be applied as follows: If the information is received by December 31, or if the client is claiming dire need, only recover an amount equal to what would have been recovered if the benefit had not been interrupted, taking into account any amount already recovered from the OAS pension payment for the arrears period. If the required income information is received January 1 or later and the client is not claiming dire need, apply the full arrears to the overpayment. The available statuses of the liability offset records on the Liability Offset list screen are: Table 2–—Statuses of Liability Offset Records Status Details Pending Approval The Pending Approval status is displayed when the Delegation of Authority has completed a batch run for the liability offset record, which creates arrears and underpayment records on the Liability Offset List screen for the corresponding arrear coverage period. In this case, you may approve the liability offset record. Pending Offset The Pending Offset status is displayed: when there are liabilities to offset, and you click the Approved action in the liability record's menu. while awaiting the Offset Delegation of Authority process. during a Delegation of Authority and Offset batch, when Delegation of Authority approval is not needed and there are liabilities that must be offset, the pending Offset status will be displayed. Completed The Completed status is displayed: when the offset is approved. when you click Save on the Offset wizard and the offset amount available is 0. when you click the Complete action menu. Processed The Processed status is displayed when the offset has been processed. Cancelled The Cancelled status is displayed when a new entitlement has been determined for this arrears period. Refer to Cross Program Recovery (Scenario) . New Ensure to close the associated task once you have completed all the required actions. What you need to know Clients can use the client portal to apply for, update and track the status of their application for the OAS pension and benefits. Clients can access their correspondence sent from OAS and receive notifications through the portal. The client portal features allow clients to submit required information during the initial benefit application, update life events information and submit requests for reconsideration. H2 Exp-coll: Initial benefit application Clients can apply for the following pension and benefits through the client portal: OAS pension; GIS ; and ALW or ALWS benefit. When applying for these benefits, actions and tasks are triggered in Cúram in the Person record and Application Case. Note: The initial pension or benefit application does not necessarily mean that the client has never applied for a benefit before. The following scenarios outline when a client's application would be considered an initial benefit application, even if it's not their first time applying for a benefit: The client previously applied for benefits but was denied. The client previously applied for benefits but withdrew or cancelled their application. The client was previously auto-enrolled to receive benefits but opted out. The client was an International Operations (IO) client with foreign benefits and is now applying for OAS benefits. Person record A Person record is created when clients apply for any benefit through the client portal. The benefit application then triggers a task in Cúram. You must then validate the following pieces of evidence: Birth and Death Details ; Identification ; and Names . Note: The pieces of evidence mentioned above will only require validation if the SIN/SIR validation process has failed. If the SIN/SIR validation was successful and the information provided in the evidence match, there is no validation required. Some pieces of evidence active in Cúram as soon as clients provide the information in the client portal. The following pieces of evidence do not require any additional action: Addresses ; Contact Preferences ; Gender Details ; Marital Status ; Phone Number; Bank Account ; and Social Insurance Number (SIN) . Note: The SIN evidence will be auto activated in most cases. When the automatic validation fails, Cúram will create a task to indicate that the evidence must be verified under the Tasks tab. You must complete a manual verification of the evidence under the Evidence and Demographics tab. If the client had previously applied for a benefit and the information provided above differs from the previous evidence on file, you must validate and activate the updated pieces of evidence. Clients can upload and submit documents in the client portal to facilitate the verification process or for a reconsideration request. The client portal instructs clients to upload any of the following documents to facilitate the verification process: Government issued ID Evidence of legal status (Citizenship card, PR card, etc.) Birth certificate Marriage certificate Names Baptismal Certificate/Records Citizenship or Immigration Records Marriage Certificate/Records Foreign Documents Affidavit/Declaration Census Church Records Educational Records Employment/Pension Records Private/Personal Records Indian Treaty Status Card Métis Scrip Records Insurance or Government Annuities Medical Records Military Service or Veterans Affairs Public and Vital Statistics Other You can immediately view documents uploaded by clients in Cúram as evidence to be verified on the Person record, under the Evidence and Demographics tab. Application case An Application Case is created in Cúram when clients apply for benefits through the client portal. The following evidence must be verified in the Application Case, if applicable: Retirement or Pension Reduction ; Attestation; Voluntary Tax Withhold ; Application Details ; Marital Relationship; Residence Period ; Consent and Declaration ; Sponsorship ; Foreign Income ; World Income Evidence ; Legal Status ; First Entry Into Canada Details ; Birth and Death Details ; Names ; and SIN verification requirement . Once all information is gathered and verified, you must authorize the Application Case for the benefit application to be approved. If the application is approved, the client is eligible for a benefit and their entitlement is determined. An Integrated Case and Product Delivery Case are created. H2 Exp-coll: Life events information update There are several life events that allow clients to manage their OAS pension and benefits in the client portal. These life events are found in the Profile section under the Tell us if anything has changed section of the Profile page. Clients can update the following life events information in the client portal: Manage Email Addresses Manage Living Apart for Reasons Beyond your Control Manage Marital Relationship Manage My Authorized Person Manage My Income Manage My Payment Destination Manage My Phone Number Manage Voluntary Income Tax Deductions Manage address information Update Communication Preferences Withdraw Old Age Security request For each life event, clients are prompted to provide various types of information. Clients can also upload documents as part of managing their account. Changes that clients make in the client portal is automatically reflected in the Person record, Application Case and/or Integrated Case in Cúram. However, certain evidence, as listed below, will have an "Evidence In Edit" or "Items to Verify" icon next to them to indicate the evidence needs to be validate. Person record Updates made in the client portal will not require any verification to be completed in the Person record. Application case If updates are made to the following evidence in the client portal, a verification task is triggered on the Application Case: Marital Status ; and Living Apart for Reasons Beyond Control . Integrated case The following evidence need to be verified in the Integrated Case, if they have been updated: Marital Status ; and Living Apart for Reasons Beyond Control . Note: Any verification that has been applied on the Integrated Case is also applied on the Application Case automatically. H2 Exp-coll: Request for reconsideration Clients can submit a request for reconsideration through the client portal anytime they disagree with a decision made on their case. When a client submits a request for reconsideration from the client portal, Cúram automatically displays a corresponding reconsideration flag. The reconsideration flag is found on the Context Panel for the Person and/or Prospect person and associated cases for the client. A request for reconsideration task is created in the appropriate work queue. Note: Do not authorize any application when there is an open Reconsideration for the client. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05468&amp;cid=CAT-02019</reference><title>View Cash Receipts in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with steps to view cash receipts in Cúram. What you need to know Cash Receipts refer to money received in Employment and Social Development Canada to apply towards departmental debts that are managed in Public Sector Collections and Disbursements (PSCD). Normally this money is received either via online banking, cheques or through cross program deductions. Cash receipts are stored under the Financials tab under a person profile or overpayment case in Cúram. When PSCD receives payments to apply against a client's liability, the payment details are sent to Cúram to be stored as a cash receipt. This is the same process involved when PSCD receives cross program liability payments from CPP towards an OAS debt. Cash receipts are generated by the system, and Cúram will record the cash receipt under the user's profile while automatically reducing the outstanding balance of the liability. Additionally, PSCD can send a Cash Receipt Reversal to Cúram to reverse a previously sent cash receipt. Cúram will process this information and add the cash receipt amount back to the outstanding balance of the liability. The cash receipt table displays specific details about the payment. The Method column indicates the source from which the amount was received. The Amount column shows the total payment received. The PSCD Details and Allocations sections are located below the main table. These sections can be expanded by clicking the ( &gt; ) toggle icon next to each section. The Allocations section displays the liability to which the payment was allocated towards, along with the respective dollar amount. Note: When Cúram receives cash receipt details from PSCD, the system automatically processes the information without the need for manual intervention by a worker. This includes both the receipts of payment and allocation processing. Furthermore, you will not have the ability to apply cash receipts or reimburse them in Cúram, these tasks are all managed via PSCD and the interface. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: View a cash receipt from a person profile In Cúram, go to client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Financials tab. Click the Transactions tab in the page group navigation bar on the left to view a list of cash receipts for the Person profile. H2 Exp-coll: View a cash receipt from an overpayment case In Cúram, go to client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Cases and Applications tab. Click Cases in the page group navigation bar on the left. Go to the overpayment case. Refer to Overpayment (Manual) Case—Add, View, Edit, Suspend and Delete in Cúram (Action) . Click the Financials tab. Click the Transactions tab in the page group navigation bar on the left to view a list of cash receipts for the Overpayment case. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05469&amp;cid=CAT-02021</reference><title>Third Party Contacts—Add, View, Edit, and Delete in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with the steps to add, view, edit and delete a third party contact in Cúram. What you need to know In Cúram, you can add third party contacts as either an Individual or an External Party organization. In either case, a profile is created to manage the third party contact information (e.g. direct deposit information, address, phone number). To add or modify a third party representative's financial information, refer to Third Party Direct Deposit Information—Add, View and Edit in Cúram (Action) . To modify a third party representative's contact information, refer to Register a Third-Party Organization, Office and Office Member in Cúram (Action) . All External Third Party organizations must be registered before they can be added as a third party contact. If they are not registered, refer to Register a Third-Party Organization, Office and Office Member in Cúram (Action) before proceeding. Table 1—Third party roles and their definitions Role Direction Trustee Non-Accounting Select this role when a trustee accounting report is not required (e.g. court appointed, committee or provincially appointed). Trustee Accounting Updated Select this role when a trustee accounting report is required (i.e. Department appointed trustees). Bulk Payee/Public Trustee Select this role when an individual is acting for a client who has no family or other representative to act on their behalf. The public trustees work under legislation specific to the province or territory where the client resides. A trustee accounting report is not required. Trustee Supporting Select this role when there is a second trustee of a joint trustee agreement. This role is for information purposes only. Tutor Select this role when the third party is a court-appointed individual that has the authority and responsibility to make financial decisions on an individual's behalf when they no longer have the capability to manage their affairs. This role is used only in Quebec. Power of Attorney Select this role when the client authorizes another individual or agency to act on their behalf. The client must be mentally capable of making their own decisions at the time the Power of Attorney (POA) is executed. Power of Attorney Supporting Select this role when a client designates more than one primary POA. Representative Select this role when a client authorizes another person or organization to communicate with the Department. This role is used only as a consent to communicate information related to the client, and the representative can check the application status, the client’s information or their benefits or pensions. However, they cannot make any changes or updates to their information. Representative records are only created for unverified contacts for correspondence. Authorization to Deduct Social Services Select this role to allow for a one-time reimbursement of social assistance benefits to a provincial agency. Authorization to Disclose Information Do not select this role. If a client submits an authorization to disclose information request, select Representative . Barrister/Solicitor Select this role when the client authorizes a barrister or solicitor to receive specific information on their behalf. Social Worker Select this role when the client authorizes a social worker to receive specific information on their behalf. Accountant Select this role when the client authorizes an accountant to receive specific information on their behalf. Estate Representative Select this role when the client authorizes an estate representative. You must have received a legal will to use this role. Witness of Application Select this role when an application is signed by a witness on behalf of the client. Executor Select this role when a legal representative is: an executor for the estate named in the individual's will after their death; or an estate administrator appointed by a court when there is no will and no named executor. An executor or court-appointed administrator's role is to act and communicate on behalf of the estate. Legal Representative of the Estate Select this role when the third party is the legal representative of a deceased client's estate. Administrator Appointed by the Courts Select this role when an administrator is appointed by the courts and is responsible for submitting a trustee's accounting report. Personal Select this role when a client authorizes a friend to receive information on their behalf. International Select this role when a client, living in or outside of Canada, authorizes official individuals or agencies, located in or outside of Canada, to liaise with International Operations and foreign pension organizations. Individuals or agencies can only exchange the information allowed under each applicable International Social Security Agreement. Mandatary Select this role when an individual is legally designated for the client in the province of Québec. They are equivalent to power of attorneys. Post Mortem Business Select this role when the client is deceased and an individual or organization submits a post-mortem benefit application for the client, as well as when payments or correspondence needs to be sent on behalf of the deceased client and there is no estate representative. Person Confirming Canadian Residence Select this role when the client indicates a name and contact information for a person who can confirm their residence in Canada. Notified department of death Updated Select this role for the name and contact information of the person who contacted the Department to advise of a client's death (it may be a next of kin or another person). Patronato Select this role to allow an authorized agency to communicate personal information concerning OAS or CPP benefits, payments, income, contributions and changes to address (excluding the address where the cheque is mailed or the bank account where the payment is deposited). For the Estate of Select this role when an individual, other than the estate representative, applies for the DTH benefit for the client. If they are eligible, these applicants cannot receive any post-mortem benefits and correspondence for the client, only that related to the DTH benefit. Note: This option is only used for CPP. Mandatory supporting Select this role when a client designates more than one primary mandatary. Tutor supporting Select this role when a client designates more than one primary tutor. Assistant Select this role when someone living with a difficulty chooses someone to help with the administration of their property or the exercise of their rights. Although assistants are not court-appointed, they are recognized by the public curator and are publicly registered to act as an intermediary between the individual living with a difficulty and third parties, including government departments. Temporary Representative Select this role when a client is incapable and the court authorizes an individual as a temporary representative. Liquidator Do not select this role. Instead, refer to the Executor role above. Certain role types are eligible to be assigned as the case nominee. For more information, refer to Manage Payment Destination for Nominees—Add, Edit and View in Cúram (Action) . Once you add a verified third party contact, Cúram allows you to send correspondence to them directly. When you add verified third party contacts, you must always ensure that proper documentation is received. In rare cases, a client can have an unverified third party contact. For example, if a client dies or becomes incapable, insufficient documentation may be received by an unverified third party. In such cases where further documentation is required to verify the contact or additional communication is necessary, you must create an unverified contact to communicate with the unverified individual. Refer to Unverified Contacts—Add, Edit, and Cancel in Cúram (Action) . Note: When you register or maintain a third party contact, you must confirm that there is a correct mailing address. After you create a Third Party Contact evidence, you can only modify the Third Party Correspondence field, as well as the From and To date fields. The Program , Role , Role Type , Language Preference and Relationship to client fields cannot be modified. The only third party information sent to ITRDS is the Third Party Contact evidence with the role of Representative . This occurs only if CPP is checked in the Program box for the Third Party Contact evidence. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05470&amp;cid=CAT-02019</reference><title>Manage Penalties and Interest on Overpayments in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[5445, 5528, 5446, 5527, 5444, 5526]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['TL - Create Outstanding Balance for Interest', 'OF - Create Outstanding Balance for Interest', 'TL - Modify Penalty (Outstanding Balance) for OAS', 'OF - Modify Penalty (Outstanding Balance) for OAS', 'TL - Create Penalty (Outstanding Balance) for OAS', 'OF - Create Penalty (Outstanding Balance) for OAS']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with the steps to add, edit, delete, activate or deactivate interest and penalties on overpayments in Cúram. Interest or penalties can be applied to clients, third-party debtors (who have their own account), and non-beneficiary debtors. What you need to know An overpayment case is typically used to rectify a situation where a pension or benefit has been recalculated. In the case of penalties, they are monetary amounts imposed on an individual who has knowingly misrepresented information in relation to CPP or OAS benefits or pensions. The amount of the imposed penalty is determined by the Department, considering factors related to the individual case. Interest is continuously calculated on unpaid penalties and their related overpayments. The Department treats penalties and interest as liabilities that must be repaid by the client. In terms of collecting the money owed for penalties and interest, the Department follows the same procedures as they would for other departmental receivables (e.g. overpayments). There are certain transactions that will result in updates to any penalties and/or interest being made to the Public Sector Collections and Disbursements (PSCD) system. Penalties and Interest: All deductions applied to penalties and interest will be sent to PSCD. Liability deactivation will not transmit to PSCD and will require staff members to manually apply locks to the debt in PSCD to ensure that no further collections occur while it is deactivated. Penalties only Any delete transactions will send PSCD a debt adjustment transaction. Any changes made to the penalty amount not related to remissions, recissions, and write-offs under the Financial Administration Act , will be sent to PSCD as a debt adjustment. Edits related to remissions, recissions and write-offs under the Financial Administration Act will not be transmitted to PSCD as they are expected to originate in PSCD and be transmitted to Cúram. Interest only Any changes made to the interest will not be sent to PSCD and care must be given to ensure that PSCD and Cúram stay in balance. In addition, recovery rates for penalties and interest will be calculated using the maximum deduction amount functionality. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: Create a penalty In Cúram, go to the client's profile, as applicable. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Financials tab. Click Outstanding Balance on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click New Outstanding Balance . The Outstanding Balance Recovery wizard opens. Enter the following details: Table 1—Fields and Directions under the Outstanding Balance Recovery window Field Direction Create Reason Mandatory Select one of the following reasons for creating the liability from the Create Reason drop-down menu: Minister Authorized Other Reallocation Note: You must enter comments in the Comment field if you select Other . Liability Type Mandatory Select one of the following options from the Liability Type drop-down menu : Penalty–OAS Penalty–OAS Non-Beneficiary Liability Amount Mandatory Enter the penalty amount. Enter comments in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Next . The wizard continues to the Select Benefit type window. Enter the following details: Table 2—Fields and Directions under the Select Benefit Type window Field Direction Product Delivery Cases Check the box for the appropriate product delivery case. Penalty Details Note: This option is only available if you selected Penalty–OAS or Penalty–OAS Non-Beneficiary in the Liability Type drop-down menu of the previous window and if the associated overpayment to the penalty exists Select the overpayment case you want to apply the penalty to from the list. Click Save . Cúram validates the information, adds the outstanding balance and returns to the Outstanding Balance window. H2 Exp-coll: Create interest Updated In Cúram, go to the client's profile, as applicable. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Financials tab. Click Outstanding Balance on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click New Outstanding Balance . The Outstanding Balance Recovery wizard opens.
