Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05489&amp;cid=CAT-02019</reference><title>View Tax Slips in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with the steps to view a client's tax slips in Cúram. What you need to know There are 2 types of tax slips that can be viewed in Cúram: The T4A (OAS) is generated for clients who received any payment in Canada or deemed residents. It is used for reporting OAS pension income. It shows the amount of OAS pension received during the year. The NR4 (OAS) is generated for clients who received any OAS pension payment outside of Canada. It reports amounts paid or credited to non-residents of Canada, including pensions, annuities and other income. It indicates the type of income paid, the total amount, and the amount of Canadian tax withheld. It is used to assist in claiming a refund for overpaid taxes or in paying additional taxes owed. Note: The 2 types of tax slips can be viewed from the perspective of Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) and Revenu Québec . There are 3 categories of tax slips within each type: Original Amended Cancelled Tax slips have one of the following Issuance Status : Submitted – the tax slip has been generated but not yet processed or released Issued – the tax slip has been already processed or released to CRA and/or Revenu Québec Draft – the tax slip data has been generated but not yet ready to be processed or released Deleted – the tax slip version has been deleted Note: Issuance status is not the same as Printing status. Tax slips have one of the following Printing Status : Submitted – the tax slip is ready to be printed but has not yet been sent to the print provider Sent – the tax slip has been sent to the print provider Intercepted – the tax slip with Submitted or Sent status is intercepted by an agent from the Correspondence tab Draft – the tax slip is saved but not issued Deleted – the tax slip is deleted and should not be picked by the printing batch to be processed Error – an error occurred while processing the tax slip The Tax Slips list shows the latest version of each tax slip for a given client, tax year and tax slip form type, regardless of whether the status is Submitted, Issued, Draft or Deleted . The following table provides descriptions of the information shown on a tax slip: Table 1—Information shown on the Tax Slip window Field Description Taxation Year The Taxation Year field shows the year in which the tax slip was issued. Type of Slip The Type of Slip field shows the type of tax slip for beneficiaries of the OAS pension program. Types of slips include: T4A (OAS) NR4 (OAS) Category The Category field shows the status of this tax slip version from the perspective of CRA and Revenu Québec . Category types include: Original Amended Cancelled Issuance Status The Issuance Status field shows whether this tax slip version has been issued or not. The issuance status types include: Submitted Draft Issued Deleted Printing Status The Printing Status field shows whether this tax slip version has been released or processed. The tax slip printing status types include: Submitted Sent Intercepted Draft Deleted Error Creation Method The Creation Method field shows whether the tax slip data was entirely system-generated or was modified by a user. The creation method types include: System Manual Status Date The Status Date field shows the date the status was set. The default sort order is descending, by date. You can view and sort the tax slips using the following columns: Taxation Year Type of slip Category Issuance Status Processing Status Creation Method Status Date Note: When multiple tax slips exist on a client account, you can view all tax slips for each taxation year. You can expand a tax slip in the main list to see the tax slip details: If you expand the latest version of a tax slip, Cúram displays the following information: recipient details for the selected tax slip (e.g. name, SIN and mailing address) the Box Name and Box Value details for each Box Number listed for the selected tax slip a list of prior versions of the tax slip If you expand the prior version of a tax slip, Cúram displays the following information: recipient details for the selected tax slip the Box Name and Box Value details for each Box Number listed for the selected tax slip If you expand a NR4 (OAS) tax slip, Cúram displays the following information: Table 2—Fields and Description for NR4 (OAS) Tax Slips Field Description Last Name The Last Name field shows the client's last name. First Name The First Name field shows the client's first name. Initials The Initials field shows the client's initials. Social Insurance Number The Social Insurance Number field shows the client's SIN. Mailing Address The Mailing Address field shows the client's mailing address. Box Number The Box Number field shows the number included in a particular box on the client's tax slip (e.g. 018). Box Name The Box Name field shows the name included in a particular box on the client's tax slip (e.g. SIN or OAS number). Box Value The Box Value field shows the amount being paid or deducted (e.g. 2,110.20). New Note: Tax slips prior to 2023 are not available and cannot be requested in Cúram. If a tax slip prior to 2023 is required, you must send an email request to the Operations GD box to retrieve the tax slip from the Data View tool. No protocol in Cúram exists at this time for making such requests and they must be made on a case-by-case basis. New Note: When issuing a tax slip after an address change, the old address will still appear on the duplicate request in Cúram. The system will automatically send the duplicate to the new address on file. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do View tax slip information In Cúram, go to the client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Financials tab. Click Tax Slips in the page group navigation bar on the left. The Tax Slips page opens and displays rows of tax slips that have been generated for the client, regardless of the status. Note: The tax slips are sorted in descending order by taxation year by default. Navigate to the tax slip you want to view. Click the ( &gt; ) toggle icon to expand the row and view the tax slip information. Top tab: References There is no reference material. (KA-01423 Snippet 14.0 content. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05490&amp;cid=CAT-02017</reference><title>Marital Evidence—Add, Edit, View, and Delete in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>['https://014gc.sharepoint.com/:w:/r/sites/95530/_layouts/15/Doc.aspx?sourcedoc=%7B54277CDF-0DFE-44F5-A2D0-9F11500BBD8D%7D&amp;file=Marital%20Evidence%20-%20Learning%20and%20Troubleshooting%20Document.docx&amp;wdLOR=c373BB4C4-BDF5-4E36-B0FC-8578FB433A12&amp;action=default&amp;mobileredirect=true']</video_link><video_name>['Marital Evidence - Learning and Troubleshooting Document.docx']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with the steps to add and manage marital relationship, living apart for reasons beyond control and consent to be disadvantaged evidence for a client in Cúram. What you need to know Marital status evidence Marital Status evidence exists at the person level and captures a client's legal marital status. This evidence is not used by Eligibility and Entitlement rules. For the purposes of OAS, Marital Relationship evidence, which tracks an actual link to another participant, is used. Marital status on the Person is automatically updated based on marital relationship evidence created and activated on the application case or integrated case. Changes to the marital status must be performed by updating the marital relationship evidence once it exists Marital relationship evidence Marital Relationship evidence on an OAS/ GIS Application case or Integrated case records the relationship details such as the relationship status, duration, and related participant. The start date identifies when a relationship starts, and the effective date of change is used to indicate the date that a relationship status changes. Updates to Marital Relationship evidence are used to update the person-level Marital Status evidence. When this evidence is activated with no outstanding verifications or evidence issues, the primary participant's Marital Status evidence is automatically updated to match the Marital Relationship evidence for both participants. Example: James Smith's Marital Status evidence was Single when his person profile was created in Cúram. On the Application Case, the Marital Relationship evidence was updated indicating that he was Married. The Marital Status evidence on James' person profile will update automatically to Married. This will also be reflected on James' partners' person profile. Living apart for reasons beyond control evidence Living apart for reasons beyond control evidence captures the reason why a client and their spouse are living apart when this living arrangement is beyond their control. A client can have multiple periods of living apart for reasons beyond control during a marital relationship resulting in multiple evidence records. Each living apart for reasons beyond control evidence can have a single related consent to be disadvantaged evidence. When a couple is living apart for reasons beyond control, if it is to the overall advantage of the couple but to the disadvantage of one member to be paid using Rate Table 1, the client who is disadvantaged must give consent to receive a lower entitlement amount. Marital relationship, living apart for reasons beyond control and consent to be disadvantaged evidence records are used to determine the financial household for income-tested benefits. It is important that these 3 evidences are added in this order. Note: If a client has multiple periods of living apart for reasons beyond control in the same marital relationship, they must give consent for each period. A client can change their consent during a period when they are living apart for a reason beyond their control. The evidence exists in both Application Cases and Integrated Cases. If the OAS benefit is not approved, the marital relationship, living apart for reasons beyond control and consent to be disadvantaged evidence is maintained in the Application Case. If the benefit is authorized and approved, the marital relationship, living apart for reasons beyond control and consent to be disadvantaged evidence is maintained in the Integrated Case. Migrated accounts New For migrated accounts, the marital relationship start date is set to the month before the 1st month of entitlement in Cúram. This has 2 implications: For any retroactive marital relationship changes before the implementation of Cúram, the marital relationship evidence must be updated to the actual start date of the relationship, so that the subsequent change can be accurately captured. This includes adding periods where the client and their spouse or common-law partner are living apart for reasons beyond control, or periods where one spouse or common-law partner gives consent to receive a lower entitlement amount for periods living apart for reasons beyond control. Income is shared across spousal cases for periods where the client is in an active relationship. If there are any income evidences that need to be shared to the case of the spouse or common-law partner, the marital relationship must be updated to indicate that there was an active relationship during the period for which income must be shared. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do Marital status evidence New H2 Exp-coll: Edit Marital Status evidence Note: Marital status evidence is added automatically when a person is registered. The Marital Status cannot be modified if a Marital Relationship exists on an Application Case that is not closed or Integrated Case. In Cúram, go to the client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Evidence tab. Click the Marital Status evidence hyperlink. The Evidence screen opens. Click the ( &gt; ) toggle icon to show the marital status evidence. Click Edit on the right side of the evidence. The Edit Marital Status evidence screen opens. Make the necessary updates to the marital status evidence. Enter the comments in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Save . Migrated accounts New H2 Exp-coll: Update the marital relationship evidence start date New If the Start Date is incorrect for both the primary client and their spouse or common-law partner, the steps below must be followed to correct the start dates on both accounts. Search for the primary client in Cúram. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Cases and Applications tab on the navigation bar. Click Cases on the page group navigation bar. Click the hyperlinked Reference name of the Old Age Security case (i.e. Integrated Case) where the client is a Primary Client. The Integrated Case opens. Click the Evidence tab. Click the hyperlinked Marital Relationship evidence under the Household cluster. Click the toggle ( &gt; ) icon to show the Marital Relationship evidence. Click Edit . The Edit Marital Relationship window opens. Edit the Start Date to the original start date of the relationship based on legacy data. Click Save . Close the Marital Relationship tab. The Integrated Case is still open. Click Verifications on the page group navigation bar. Click Add Proof for the Marital Relationship. The Verification window opens. Use the existing proof based on legacy data. If there is limited or no proof in legacy data but the marital status is confirmed as accurate, use the following information for the marital verification: Set Item as Other . Select the Primary Client as Case Participant . Set the Acceptance Status to Accepted . Click Next . Select the Marital Relationship . Click Save . Click Apply Evidence Changes . Select the Marital Relationship record. Click Save . Note: If a spouse’s date of death is before the migrated Marital Relationship Start Date (i.e. prior to March 1st, 2025), the updates to the marital relationship Start Date must be completed before updating the marital relationship Effective Date of Change with the spouse’s date of death. Once both spouses’ marital relationship evidences are corrected with the appropriate start dates, any further changes (e.g. change in Relationship Status ) can be made as outlined in the Edit Marital Status evidence section above. Note: If a client’s Relationship Status has changed before the migrated Marital Relationship Start Date (i.e. Before March 1st, 2025), the updates to the marital relationship Start Date must be completed before updating the Relationship Status and Effective Date of Change with the new information received. Once both spouses’ marital relationship evidences are corrected with the appropriate start dates, any further changes (e.g. change in Relationship Status ) can be made as outlined in the Edit Marital Status evidence section above. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05492&amp;cid=CAT-02019</reference><title>Underpayments—View and Edit Issuance in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary Updated This procedure provides you with the steps to view underpayments or arrears in Cúram, understand the process for modifying the issuance details of an underpayment, approve an underpayment and manage and process retroactive (i.e. backdated) payments for unpaid months in Cúram. What you need to know Cúram creates an underpayment when it determines that a client was paid less for a past period than they were entitled to. Cúram reassesses entitlement to each OAS pension or benefit when new evidence is added, or when existing evidence is updated and activated. When Cúram reassesses a client's entitlement and a new entitlement is determined for a past period, the system compares this new entitlement to the past issued entitlement amount to determine if an underpayment exists. If the new amount is higher than the previously issued amount, the individual is determined to have been underpaid and Cúram automatically creates a Payment Correction – Underpaid case. This case can be found under the Cases and Applications tab. Updated Payments that would have been due to the client had they been enrolled in a program before their actual date of enrollment are not processed as underpayments in Cúram. If a client is determined to be eligible for a pension or benefit for a past period when no payment was issued, the payments that the client would have been eligible for will be processed as arrears rather than as underpayments. An arrears payment is a retroactive payment that has not previously been assessed. Note: After adding or modifying evidence on an Integrated Case and before activating the change, you must run an eligibility check to avoid unnecessary underpayment cases from being created. Refer to Eligibility and Entitlement Override Evidence—Add, Edit, View, and Delete in Cúram (Action) . Each OAS pension or benefit for the client is assessed separately. If a client receives multiple OAS benefits and Cúram determines that more than one of those benefits were underpaid in the same period, a separate Correction – Underpaid case is created for each benefit. Each specific period in which it has been determined that the client has been underpaid is recorded as a separate transaction. By default, the sum of all underpayments will be resolved at the time the client is next scheduled to receive a payment. The issuance of an underpayment can be modified manually in Cúram. When assessing what to modify the underpayment issuance to, the Department's representative must review the Operational Payment Production Schedule to determine when they want the client to receive the payment by. Once the issuance of an underpayment is manually modified, the dates of issuance will be based on a production schedule set by the Department. You can view underpayments within a product delivery case on the Over and Under Payments page in the Financials tab. Underpayments can only be created in Cúram via system generated reassessments. Any situations where Cúram is unable to reassess entitlement are manually calculated and issued outside of Cúram. Approval is required for underpayments and arrears that are above $15,000. In these situations, you must follow the Delegation of Authority process. Cúram does not automatically apply underpayments or arrears against existing overpayments to offset them. Whenever an underpayment or arrears is generated and there is an overpayment for the client, staff will need to manually apply any underpayments or arrears to the overpayment using the offset process. Action Description New Issue Arrears payments All arrears payments will be picked up on the next weekly payment date as per the national payment schedule, unless you provide any other payment method using the Issue Retro Pending Payments window. Alternative options are priority or monthly payment. New Approve offset records linked to underpayments The issuance of underpayment or arrears is based on an associated offset record’s status. New Voluntary Tax Deduction The deduction functionality is used to deduct Voluntary Tax Withhold (VTW) from a client’s OAS benefits. The deduction functionality cannot be manually created and managed. The deduction will be created and managed via the VTW evidence. When an initial VTW evidence is activated, Cúram will automatically create a deduction record. Cúram uses 3 fields on the Deductions page group navigation bar to determine if the deduction should be used in current gross to net payment calculation: Status Start Date End Date The deduction information can be viewed at the Person Record level and the Product Delivery Case level. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: View an underpayment In Cúram, go to the person's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Cases and Applications tab on the navigation bar. Click the Reference number hyperlink of the Old Age Security Program Benefits case under the Reference column. The Old Age Security Program Benefits product delivery case opens in a new tab. Click the Financials tab on the navigation bar. Click Over and Under Payments from the page group navigation bar. The Over and Under Payments page opens. Click the drop-down toggle ( &gt; ) icon of the underpayment to expand the content page. The table shows: the period covered; the component the underpayment applies to; the previous amount; the reassessed amount; and the amount of the difference. Click the Financials tab on the navigation bar. Click Over and Under Payments from the page group navigation bar. The Over and Under Payments page opens. Click the Modify Underpayment Issuance on the Over and Under Payments content page. The Modify Underpayment Issuance window opens. Select one of the following options from the Underpayment Issuance menu: Pay by Priority Pay with next weekly schedule Pay with next Benefit Payment Click Save . What you need to know You may need to add direct deposit information to a third-party's profile so that they can receive payment on behalf of the client. There are various third-party roles that can be designated as nominees in Cúram so they can receive a payment on behalf of the client. When you add a third party with their banking information for the first time, you must first add the third party's bank account using the Financials tab on their profile. Refer to Third Party Contacts—Add, View, Edit, and Delete in Cúram (Action) . Next, you go to the client's product delivery case and add the third party as a nominee. This changes the nominee on the case from the client to the third party and the direct deposit information to that of the third party. Note: The third party contact must meet defined criteria to be added as a case nominee. Refer to Manage Payment Destination for Nominees—Add, Edit and View in Cúram (Action) . When the third party reports a new bank account, you must use the New function to add new banking information, not Edit . The Edit function can only be used to correct previously entered incorrect information when payments have not been made to that account. Once the bank account information has been added, you use the Transfer function to automatically update the product delivery case. When the direct deposit for a third party is to take effect in the future, you must create a manual task. This task should be deferred and added to the third party's profile at that future date. The reason why a manual task is needed is because the system cannot capture a future dated direct deposit information for a third party. You must use the Transfer function to update product delivery case nominee details at that time. Note: For bulk payees, when you update the direct deposit information on the external party's profile and use the Transfer option, the banking information for all the individuals under the bulk payee is updated. Refer to Manage Tasks in Cúram (Action) . Note: If a user receives any validation message regarding missing, cancelled, closed, or duplicated bank branches when attempting to add a new bank account evidence, then you must send a ticket to the National Service Desk Internal link . New Public Services and Procurement Canada (PSPC) receives data from Canadian financial institutions regarding changes to a client’s direct deposit information. Once PSPC verifies the Standard Payment System and performs updates, they will then create a Notice of Change File which is sent to the Department. New When the Notice of Change is received from PSPC to update direct deposit information, Cúram attempts to automatically update the direct deposit information for clients. If Cúram is unable to automatically update the direct deposit information based on the Notice of Change, a task will be generated. New You must review the client's information and manually add the direct deposit information. This will ensure that payment goes to the correct bank account. What you need to know Eligibility and entitlement override evidence is used when the actual detailed evidence in Cúram is insufficient to achieve the intended determination of a client's eligibility and entitlement for OAS benefits. Overrides are rarely used. Circumstances when you would add an override include: when a ministerial request is received (e.g. the Minister states that the client is eligible for a pension or benefit or meets the legal status criterion.) to comply with the determination of a court case (e.g. if the Social Security Tribunal rules that a client should be paid $300.00 a month regardless of what is on the client's file, an override would be created to reflect that judgement.) Note: An override is always created manually; it is not automatically triggered by Cúram. You can only add an override to a case when directed to do so. Note: There will be system generated overrides in Cúram due to data migration. This article strictly deals with post-migration override evidence. Note: Future determinations will use the override unless it is removed or changed. The evidence exists in both Application Cases and Integrated Cases. If the OAS benefit is not approved, the eligibility and entitlement override evidence is maintained in the Application Case. If the benefit is authorized, the eligibility and entitlement override evidence is maintained in the Integrated Case. Note: Eligibility and entitlement override evidence can be added, viewed, and deleted in the Application Case but not edited. To edit the evidence in the Application Case, you must delete the existing evidence and re-enter it. The evidence can be edited in the Integrated Case. Click the hyperlink in front of the Old Age Security case in the Reference column. Click the Evidence tab. Dollar Amount Enter the dollar amount of the override, if applicable. Note: An override amount cannot be entered in the Dollar Amount field unless the Override Value is set to Entitlement Amount , Individual Payment Income or Total Payment Income . Reason Mandatory Select the reason for the override from the Reason drop-down menu: Minister Override Court Case Other Federal Programs Other Description Enter a description of the reason if you selected Other under the Reason field. From Select the date the override will start from the calendar. Note: The override must start on the first day of the month. End Date Select the date the override will end from the calendar, if applicable. Note: The override must end on the last day of the month. Enter the comments in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Save . If the eligibility and entitlement override evidence is in an Application Case, the evidence will be active automatically. If the eligibility and entitlement override evidence is in an Integrated Case, the evidence moves to In Edit status. Refer to the Activate eligibility and entitlement override evidence section to activate the evidence. What you need to know The client is designated as the nominee by default. However, if an authorized individual or an organization will receive the benefit payments on behalf of a client, they can be designated as a nominee. An individual or an organization must be registered in Cúram either as a representative or external party participant before being added as a nominee to a client's product delivery case. Refer to Application Case, Integrated Case and Product Delivery Case in Cúram (Knowledge) . Multiple case nominees can be added; however, only one case nominee can be the current nominee. The following criteria must be met to add a person and third party contacts as a case nominee: The case is an OAS Product Delivery Case and the client has an Active status for the OAS program. The third party contact must have no end date specified. If there is an end-date associated with the third party contact, you must update it before adding the third party contact as the case nominee. The nominee must have one of the following third party contact role types: Administrator Appointed by the Courts Bulk Pay/Public Trustee Executor For the Estate of Legal Representative of the Estate Post-mortem Business Trustee Accounting Trustee Non-Accounting Estate Representative Tutor Mandatary (where 'Power Of Attorney (POA)/Mandate Type' = 'Protection) Liquidator To add: a representative, refer to Third Party Contacts—Add, View, Edit, and Delete in Cúram (Action) . an External Party Participant, refer to Register a Third-Party Organization, Office and Office Member in Cúram (Action) . Only third party contacts that meet the criteria and have an Active status can be added as nominees for a client. The third party contact must have a valid bank account and/or a mailing address on their account. Refer to Third Party Contacts—Add, View, Edit, and Delete in Cúram (Action) . H2 Exp-coll: Establishing payment method and frequency for nominees You must select a delivery pattern for the payment before saving the nominee. The delivery pattern specifies the type of payment (i.e. cheque or direct deposit) and the frequency at which the nominee will receive the payment (monthly, semi-annually, etc.). When the delivery pattern payment type is set to Cheque , a mailing address must be on file. When you assign a new case nominee, you must also assign the dedicated delivery pattern. You can select and change between the available nominees. When a Public Trustee is initially set up, a method of payment is already specified. Therefore, when you add a Public Trustee as a nominee for a client, you must first review the Public Trustee profile to verify the specified method of payment and frequency and ensure you select it as the Delivery Pattern . H2 Exp-coll: Deleting a third party nominee When a payment has been made to a third party nominee, you will not be able to delete them from the Product Delivery Case. You will be able to end date the third party nominee; however, the status of the nominee will still be Active . You will receive an error message if you try to designate them as a nominee. If the third party has not received a payment, the third party contact can be deleted. When a third party nominee was added in error and no payment was made to the third party nominee, you can delete the third party nominee. The third party nominee will still be displayed on Product Delivery Case with a status of Inactive . For more information, refer to Third Party Contacts—Add, View, Edit, and Delete in Cúram (Action) . H2 Exp-coll: Updating nominee address and direct deposit information To change address or direct deposit information of the nominee, you must add the new address or direct deposit information in the Third Party's profile. This change will automatically update the address or direct deposit for the nominee on the Product Delivery Case. If the mailing address is updated on the Third Party's profile, it will update the mailing address on the nominee record automatically. Both the mailing and residential address will show in the Change Nominee Address drop-down menu but there is no need to use this as the address is updated when the mailing address is updated on the representative profile. Bring forward tasks may need to be created for future dated nominee changes to banking or address information. When creating bring forward tasks for future dated nominees, the category OAS – maintenance must be selected followed by selecting the applicable type of task. Refer to Manage Tasks in Cúram (Action) to create a bring forward task. H2 Exp-coll: Bank Account Fraud List New When a domestic bank account is added or edited, Cúram automatically reviews the details and compares them against the Bank Account Fraud List. If the account information matches an entry on the fraud list, the validation check will fail, and the bank account evidence cannot be applied. In such cases, a task is automatically generated and sent for further review. This process does not impact the authorization of benefits. The client will still receive payment, which will be issued by cheque. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: Add a new nominee In Cúram, go to the person's profile. What you need to know The Incarceration evidence captures information about a client's period of incarceration. It is used by Eligibility and Entitlement to assess entitlement to benefits for both the incarcerated individual and their spouse or common-law partner. Since a person may be incarcerated multiple times, you can add multiple incarceration records. During the period of incarceration, the circumstances of incarceration may change (e.g. a different institution or offender status). The Effective Date of Change field is used to track changes of information during an incarceration period. The client's incarceration institution is linked in the evidence as a case participant. When you create a new incarceration evidence, you add an institution by searching for a service supplier and selecting it. This associates the institution with the evidence. If the client has previously been incarcerated, those institutions are listed in the related drop-down menu, allowing you to select that institution if the client has re-entered it. When you modify incarceration evidence, the institution drop-down menu is populated with the current institution name. The evidence exists in both Application Cases and Integrated Cases. If the OAS benefit is not approved, the incarceration evidence is maintained in the Application Case. If the benefit is authorized and approved, the incarceration evidence is maintained in the Integrated Case. Note: Bill-C591 requires that no payments of survivor’s pension, death benefit or orphan’s benefit to an individual who has been convicted of first or second degree murder or manslaughter of the contributor. It also amends the Old Age Security Act to prohibit the payment of a survivor’s allowance to an individual who has been convicted of first or second degree murder or manslaughter of the individual's spouse or common-law partner. What you need to know The consent to deduction and payments evidence captures the client's consent to reimburse benefits to the Social Assistance Agency. Additionally, there is a sub-evidence called "social assistance payment." The social assistance payments evidence captures the payment amounts that were paid by the Social Assistance Agency to the client. This amount may be reimbursed from the OAS pension payments and/or income tested benefits (i.e. GIS or ALW and ALWS benefits). Clients who are eligible for income tested benefit or pension payments (i.e. OAS pension, GIS , ALW and ALWS benefits) may receive payments from a Social Assistance Agency (municipal or provincial) for the same period. The Social Assistance Agency can request reimbursement for the payments by submitting a valid Consent to Deduction and Payment - Old Age Security (ISP-3010) form to recover all or part of the amount paid to the individual when pension and/or income tested benefit payments (OAS pension, GIS , ALW and ALWS benefits) are issued. Upon receiving the ISP-3010 form from the Social Assistance Agency, you must make sure it is registered as an external party in Cúram before updating the evidence. Note: Only add Social Assistance Agencies that are based in Canada. In Cúram, the consent to deduction and payment evidence is the parent evidence of the social assistance payments. You must ensure the consent to deduction and payment evidence is active before making any changes to the social assistance payments evidence. The evidence exists in Application Cases and Integrated Cases and can also exist in the Person / Prospect Person profile. Note: When an ISP-3010 form has been received but there is insufficient information to register the client, you can create a Prospect Person to capture the Consent to Deduction evidence. Once further information about the client has been received, then the Prospect person can be upgraded to a Person. If the benefit is not approved, the consent to deduction and payments evidence is maintained in the Application Case. If the benefit is approved, the consent to deduction and payments evidence is automatically brokered to and maintained in the Integrated Case. If the client is found to be ineligible within 12 months of receiving the ISP-3010 form, then a Department's representative must manually send a rejection letter to the Social Assistance Agency. It also provides you with the steps to request CRA data as evidence for a case. What you need to know The CRA income evidence contains income information shared by the CRA . This evidence may impact a client's eligibility and entitlement for income-tested benefits. Cúram will request CRA income data: when an application for an income-tested benefit is submitted; and/or when the request to add a client to the CRA Lifetime List is sent. As a result of the request, the CRA will automatically return the income information for the base calendar year and the following years. Updated You only need to perform a manual request if there is no available income data and you have determined that this information is required to assess eligibility. In those cases, you can manually request a person’s CRA income data by using the New CRA Request wizard in the Interfaces tab in an Application Case or an Integrated Case. Updated Regardless of how Cúram receives CRA income data, the data may need to be reviewed and validated. Refer to Validate Income for Income-Tested Benefits (Action) . The CRA income evidence cannot be edited, discarded or deleted. If you find any discrepancies or if you need to amend a client's income information, you must create a Manually Entered Income evidence for the appropriate tax year. Refer to Manually Entered Income Evidence—Add, Edit, View and Delete in Cúram (Action) . New Historical data migrated from CRA income records can be viewed from an Integrated Case in the CRA Income Data section of the Interfaces tab in an Integrated Case. These records are migrated with the line-by-line income information and are identified by the Request Type set to Migration . If the Request Type is set to Migration , no evidence will be created. New If the migrated historical CRA data includes Block 7 – Net Employment Income or Block 8 – Net Self-Employment Income , there may be a discrepancy between the total income of the migrated CRA Income evidence and the total income of the migrated CRA Interface data as the earnings exemption is not applied to historical data migrated from CRA income. It is only reflected on the CRA Income evidence’s total. New When migrated historical income is required to determine eligibility, you must create a Manually Entered Income evidence for the appropriate tax year. Refer to Manually Entered Income Evidence—Add, Edit, View and Delete in Cúram (Action) . New Note: For CRA Interface records with a Request Type of Migration , the CRA SIN , CRA Surname , CRA Birth Date and Date of Death fields are populated based on the client’s data in Cúram. This information should not be used as data provided by the CRA . What you need to know A task refers to a specific unit of work that needs to be completed as part of a larger process, or workflow. It represents an individual or collection of actions or activities that are assigned to a user within the system. These actions or activities could include reviewing documentation, collecting information, and updating evidence. Tasks are often associated with a prospect person, person, or a type of case. These tasks are used to manage and track the progress of work related to the associated target. In Cúram, tasks are created in two ways. Primarily, tasks are generated automatically by the system based on predefined rules and workflows. However, Cúram also allows the manual creation of tasks by users. Manual task creation is only to be used in specific scenarios. Each task contains attributes, history and comments, assignments, time worked, and relevant links to supporting pages based on the prospect person, person, application, or type of case. Task attributes are a set of details used to capture a task's name, status, priority, category, urgency, and more. The combination of task attributes provides key insight as to what the task is about, what information is available, what work has been previously done on the task, and what is the relevant priority for the task. Inbox A user's Inbox is the centralized location where tasks are received and managed. At any given time, a user can navigate to their inbox and review their workload. Tasks are allocated to the users based on a user's location, language, skill type (virtual skills group), and availability. At the start of a shift, and throughout the workday, users should navigate to their inbox to review their existing workload and workload that has newly been assigned. Under Inbox is the "My Tasks" tab that displays all tasks reserved to the logged in user. The "My Tasks" tab is divided in two pages: My Open Tasks, and My Deferred Tasks. In My Open Tasks, a user can view tasks that have been started, have not yet been started, or stopped. In Deferred Tasks, a user can view all tasks that have been deferred. In both task spaces, the full details of each task is displayed. All tasks in a user's Inbox are sorted by default based on their importance in being completed. While this sorting is used to indicate where a user should start, it does not prevent a user from completing other tasks in their Inbox. Note: If you previously had any Release1 tasks that were assigned, but not reserved you must first use the Available Tasks link to search for the forwarded task. Tasks that are forwarded to you and in your Available Tasks must be manually reserved as they are not part of the work queue for reporting purposes. Once you reserve the forwarded task to yourself, it will be available to view under My Open Tasks . All tasks have 4 statuses: Open On Hold Deferred Closed Note: The status of a task is Open when it is created. Tasks can be modified based on the task actions. This includes: Table 1. Task types and descriptions Task action Description Start Work This task action moves a user's task from the Stopped Work / Work Not Started list to the Started Work list. Stop Work This task action moves a user's task from the Started Work list to the Stopped Work / Work Not Started list. Add Comment This task action allows a user to add comments to a task. Edit Task This task action allows a user to update the category, type, skill type, and priority level of a task. Edit Due / Receipt Date This task action allows a user to update the due date and receipt date of a task. Bring Forward This task action allows a user to set the task to On Hold status until the bring forward date. This task will be allocated to the assigned work queue until the Bring Forward Date and will not show in the user's My Tasks list . Once the Bring Forward Date arrives, the system will set the task status back to Open . Make Available This task action makes the task available to the previous assigned. The user will no longer see the task in their My Open Tasks list. Forward This task action allows a user to forward a task assigned to them, to another user or work queue. Team leads can forward tasks that are not assigned to them. These tasks can be viewed in the Open Tasks page of the processing user's workspace or in the work queue workspace. Note: You must only use the Forward... function to reassign a task to another colleague. Do not use the Reallocate... function as that will not reassign the task correctly. Reallocate This task action allows a user to remove the task from their inbox and re-run the allocation strategy that initially allocated the task at creation. Defer This task action allows a user to set the task to Deferred status until the restart date. A task is deferred, and the task status is updated to Deferred . It will remain in the user's inbox and move into the My Deferred Tasks page. Restart This task action allows a user to manually restart a deferred task and return it to the user's My Open Tasks list. Complete This task action allows a user to update the status of a task to Completed. Note: To close a task, it must be reserved to you and in your My Open Tasks . All ongoing reserved tasks are under My Open Tasks , and all your deferred tasks are under My Deferred Tasks . When you defer an open task, you will record a restart date and the status of the task is updated from Open to Deferred . After the restart date, the deferred task will automatically reopen and move from My Deferred Tasks to My Open Tasks . You must review all ongoing tasks under My Open Tasks to determine if it is a new task or a previously deferred task that requires attention. Tasks will disappear from the list of tasks once they are closed. In each task, you will be able to: Close the task if it is completed. Note: To close a task, it must be reserved to you and in your My Open Tasks . Add a comment to the task for additional notes. Defer the task to a later date if you are waiting for a client's missing information and cannot proceed with the open task. Note: To work on a deferred task, you must restart the deferred task manually to open it. Forward the task to another colleague. Note: You must only use the Forward... function to reassign a task to another colleague. Do not use the Reallocate... function as that will not reassign the task correctly. Edit the category, type and skill type. Note: Relevant tasks must be closed before authorization. Some tasks, such as the Application Case task, will close automatically when the case is authorized, but failure to address other tasks may cause errors when authorizing the Application Case. In each task, the context panel shows the task properties: Table 2 — Field and Detail in the Task Tab Field Detail Status This field lists the status of the tasks. Reserved To This field shows whom this task is reserved to. Due Date This field lists the deadline to complete the task. Priority This field lists the priority of the task. Last Assigned This field lists when this task was last assigned. Skill type This field lists the skill type (virtual skill group - VSG) level of the task. Urgent Flags This field indicates if an urgent flag is raised in the task. Escalation Level This field indicates the escalation level for the task: Escalation Level 1 means 15 days to complete. Escalation Level 2 means 2 days to complete. Escalation Levels 3 to 8 mean one day to complete. Category This field indicates the category of the task. Refer to section Task categories and types for a full list of task categories. Type This field indicates the specific type of the task under Category . Refer to section Task categories and types for a full list of task types. Red clock icon If a task is past due, a red clock icon displays under Category . The subject of the task is shown next to the icon. In each task, there are 4 tabs under the context panel: Table 3 — Tab Name and Details for Tasks Tab Name Details Home This tab lists applicable hyperlinks under Primary Action and Supporting Information . Links under Primary Action direct you to carry out the primary action of the task. Links under Supporting Information direct you to supplemental information. History and Comments This tab records all the change actions on this task. You can also see comments entered on the task. Assignments This tab lists whom the task is assigned to. Time Worked The time that a task has been worked on by user(s). Automatic Tasks Predefined rules and workflows define the conditions and sequences in which tasks are automatically generated in Cúram. These predefined rules and conditions consider OAS business processes, activities in the client lifecycle (new applications, client maintenance), and interactions with integrated systems. Some examples include: An underpayment or arrears payment has exceeded threshold, and an authorization is required by a delegated authority. A client reports a change in residency, and the change must be reviewed for its impact on the client's benefits. A payment issue has been reported from the Standard Payment System (SPS), and the account must be investigated in Cúram. All incoming paper documents (including applications) designated with a scan location of Virtual in the Pension Trusted Digital Repository are automatically re-routed to the appropriate regional queue in Cúram based on the captured metadata. Team leaders and OAS administrators will have to monitor the workload in the OAS-INTAKE-ERROR-TASKS manual work queue to identify tasks that fail to be directed to the appropriate work queue through the automated process. Manual Tasks A user can create a manual task from their Inbox, prospect person, person, or case for specific purposes and assign it to a work queue. A user may create a manual task for the following reasons: Investigation Referral or Report Resolving Verifications for Dire Need Cases Manual Maintenance of Client Evidence Potential Duplicate Accounts You must create a manual task when you suspect that there may be a duplicate record of the same client when searching for a client in Cúram. If you need to merge duplicate records, refer to Merge Records and Access Merged Foreign Engagement Cases to Update a Master Person's Record in Cúram (Action) and Manage Duplicate Person Records in Cúram (Action) . Public Services and Procurement Canada (PSPC) receives data from Canadian financial institutions regarding changes to a client's direct deposit information. Once PSPC verifies the SPS and performs updates, they will then create a Notice of Change File which is sent to the Department. When the Notice of Change is received from PSPC to update direct deposit information, Cúram attempts to automatically update the direct deposit information for clients. If Cúram is unable to automatically update the direct deposit information based on the Notice of Change, a task will be generated. You must review the client's information and manually add the direct deposit information. This will ensure that payment goes to the correct bank account. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: Create manual tasks Create a manual task from Prospect Person / Person In Cúram, go to the client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click Tasks on the navigation bar. Click New on the page menu. The New Task window opens. Once the New Task window opens, refer to the Create a Manual Task section below. Create a manual task from Case In Cúram, go to the client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Cases and Applications tab. Determine where to add the task: To create the task on an Application Case: Click Applications on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click the hyperlink in front of the case in the Reference column. To create the task on an Integrated Case: Click Cases on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click the hyperlink in front of the Old Age Security case in the Reference column. To create the task on a Product Delivery Case: Click Cases on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click the hyperlink in front of the Old Age Security Benefit case in the Reference column. Click Tasks on the navigation bar. Click New on the page menu. The New Task window opens. Once the New Task window opens, refer to the Create a Manual Task section below. Create a manual task from My Inbox In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Select the My Tasks page. Select New Task… in the top right corner of the My Tasks page. The New Task window opens. Once the New Task window opens, refer to the Create a Manual Task section below. Note: When a manual task is created from the My Inbox page, instead of from a prospect person, person, or case, additional information is required on the Create a Manual Task window to identify who the task is concerning. This additional information is captured as part of Table 5 — Concerning Field Direction (Specifically for Manual Task Creation from My Inbox) . Create a Manual Task Enter the information in the window as follows: Table 4 — New Task Field Direction Field Direction Subject Mandatory The descriptive name or title for a task. The subject often includes the required actions a user should take when completing the task. Enter the relevant information in the Subject field in following format: &lt;SIN or Cúram Reference number&gt; - &lt;First name &gt; &lt;Last name &gt; - &lt; Description based on type of manual task&gt; Example: 123456789 - Tom Green – Evidence verification outstanding Category Mandatory The category of task based on the nature of the task. Select the appropriate Category from the drop-down menu. Type Mandatory The type of task based on the nature of a task's category. Select the appropriate Type from the drop-down menu: Receipt Date Select the date the task is received from the calendar. Priority This field lists the priority of the task. The level of priority assigned to the task. Priorities include high, medium, and low. Note: This field is prefilled with Medium but you can change the value, if required. Due Date Mandatory Select the appropriate Due Date from the calendar. Assigned to Work Queue Mandatory Assign the task to the appropriate work queue: Click the magnifying glass icon in the Assign to Work Queue field. The Select Work Queue window opens. Enter the full name or part of the name of the work queue in the Name field. Click Search . The applicable results display under Search Results. Click Select in front of the work queue. The selected work queue populates the Assign to Work Queue field on the New Task window. Skill Type The skill type (virtual skill group – VSG) required to complete a given task. H2 Exp-coll: Cúram Task Search Task Search is a Cúram functionality allowing users to search for task(s) using specific parameters . There are two standalone Task Search locations on Cúram: Task Search on Inbox and under Teams and Workload (Team lead-specific) . Table 8 – Task Search Parameters Task Search Parameters Description Task ID This is the unique identifier of the task. Assigned To The assignee of a task, including User, or Work Queue. Business Object Type The target associated with a task, a person, application or a case. Status The current state of the task. Priority The level of importance assigned to the task. Escalation Level The number of times the same request has been enquired about without resolution. Category and Type The category of task based on the nature of the task, and the type of task within the task category. Skill Type The skill type (virtual skill group - VSG) required to complete the task. Receipt Date From The starting date in the range for a task's receipt date. Note: The range between Receipt Date From and Receipt Date To must not exceed 90 days, inclusive of the Receipt Date From and Receipt Date To dates. Receipt Date To The ending date in the range for a task's receipt date. Note: The range between Receipt Date From and Receipt Date To must not exceed 90 days, inclusive of the Receipt Date From and Receipt Date To dates. Due Date From The starting date in the range for a task's due date. Note: The range between Due Date From and Due Date To must not exceed 90 days, inclusive of the Due Date From and Due Date To dates. Due Date To The ending date in the range for a task's due date. Note: The range between Due Date From and Due Date To must not exceed 90 days, inclusive of the Due Date From and Due Date To dates. Created From The starting date in the range for task creation for a given period. Note: The range between Created From and Created Date To must not exceed 90 days, inclusive of the Created Date From and Created To dates. Created To The ending date in the range for task creation for a given period. Note: The range between Created From and Created Date To must not exceed 90 days, inclusive of the Created Date From and Created To dates. A user may want to search for all tasks associated with any specific parameter(s). Some examples include: All tasks with a specific category and type All tasks due within a specific date range All tasks with a specific Urgent Flag All tasks with Priority as High, Medium, Low All tasks created within a specific date range In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Click the Shortcuts panel on the left. Select Task Search under Tasks . The Task Search tab opens in a new tab. Enter the parameters of your choice. Click Search. Review the search results. Searching Tasks Assigned to a Work Queue (Team lead) A Team lead can search for tasks assigned to a work queue from the Work Queue Workspace. A Team lead may want to search for tasks assigned to a work queue for the following reasons: When team lead needs to view details of one or more assigned tasks in the work queue. When team lead needs to action a specific assigned task in work queue. In Cúram, click the Teams and Workload tab. Click the Shortcuts panel on the left. Select My Work Queues under My Users . The My Work Queues page opens in a new tab. Select the hyperlink for the subscribed work queue you would like to search in. Enter the parameters of your choice. Select Assigned Tasks . The Assigned Tasks search page opens. Enter the parameters of your choice. Click Search. Review the search results. Searching Tasks Reserved to a Work Queue (Team Lead) A Team lead can search for reserved tasks in a work queue from the Work Queue Workspace. A Team lead may want to search for reserved tasks for the following reasons: When team lead needs to view details of one or more reserved tasks (open and deferred) in the work queue. When team lead needs to action a specific reserved task in work queue. In Cúram, click the Teams and Workload tab. Click the Shortcuts panel on the left. Select My Work Queues under My Users . The My Work Queues page opens in a new tab. Select the hyperlink for the subscribed work queue you would like to search in. Enter the parameters of your choice. Select Reserved Tasks . The Reserved Tasks search page opens. Enter the parameters of your choice. Click Search. Review the search results. H2 Exp-coll: Add comments to a task In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click Add Comment at the top right of the detailed task tab. The Add Comment window opens. Enter the comments in the Comments field. Click Save . The comments will be recorded under History and Comments . H2 Exp-coll: Start Work on a task Start Work is the most common task action a user will take. It is the action used when a user is ready to start working on a reserved task and initiate the time worked timer. A task that has been started will move to the “Started Work” cluster in a user's Inbox. Certain teams in ESDC capture the “Time Worked” for a task. To facilitate this, the user must capture the time spent on the task using the “Start Work” and “Stop Work” task actions. In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click Start Work... on the top right of the task. The Start Work window opens. Click Yes . H2 Exp-coll: Stop Work on a task A user may want to stop a task because they will be taking a pause in completing the work on the task for a period and will be returning to it later. A task that has been stopped will remain in the user's My Open Tasks list and move into the “Work Stopped / Work Not Started” cluster. The time worked is calculated and stored once the stop work in initiated. The calculation may resume once the users starts work again on this task. In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the top right of the detailed task tab and select Stop Work... . The Stop Work window opens. Enter the comments in the Comments field. Click Save . H2 Exp-coll: Bring Forward a task A user may want to bring forward a task when waiting for additional information. Any user with the required skill can complete this task in the future. A task that is brought forward will be allocated to the assigned work queue until the Bring Forward Date. This task does not show in the user's my tasks list anymore. Once the Bring Forward Date arrives, the system will set the task status back to Open . In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the top right of the detailed task tab and select Bring Forward ... . The Bring Forward Task window opens. Enter the Bring Forward date. Enter the comments in the Comments field. Click Save . H2 Exp-coll: Edit Due/Receipt Date A user may want to edit the due date or receipt date for the following reasons: A user has identified information on the task that should be corrected (Receipt Date) A user has identified information on the task that should be updated (Due Date) In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the top right of the detailed task tab and select Edit Due/Receipt Date... . The Edit Due/Receipt Date window opens. Enter in the Due Date and / or Receipt Date changes. Enter the comments in the Comments field. Click Save . H2 Exp-coll: Reallocate a task A user may want to reallocate a task because they identify that this task cannot be completed by them, and that it should be allocated based on the same system rules used at time of the task's creation. A key difference between Make Available and Reallocate , is that when the Make Available action is used, the task will be allocated to the previous assignee. However, when the Reallocate action is used, the task is allocated to the initial target (work queue). Note: For all tasks that have been data-migrated from PWS directly to a user's inbox; a user's inbox will be the first location that Cúram records the task being reserved to. If a user must ‘reallocate' tasks from their inbox that was assigned to them and data migrated from PWS , the user should use the forward function to forward the tasks to another work queue. In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the top right of the detailed task tab and select Reallocate... . The Reallocate Task window opens. Enter the comments in the Comments field. Click Save . H2 Exp-coll: Edit a task A user may want to edit a task for the following reasons: A user has identified information on the task that should be corrected (Change in Category, Type, or Skill Type) A user has identified information on the task that should be updated (Change in Priority) In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the top right of the detailed task tab and select Edit Task... . The Edit Task window opens. Select the appropriate Category, Type and/or Skill Type for the task. Enter the comments in the Comments field. Click Save . Note: For Skill Type (virtual skill group – VSG) titles and descriptions, please refer to the User skill types (virtual skill group – VSG) and descriptions section below. H2 Exp-coll: Forward a task to another user or work queue A user may want to forward a task for the following reason: A user has identified another user working on tasks associated with a common prospect person, person, or case, and forwards it to them. A user is unable to work on the task and forwards it to their team lead to appropriately reassign. A user is unable to work on the task and forwards it to a work queue so it can be picked up by another user. When moving tasks to an automated work queue, ensure that a Virtual Skills Group is listed and that the program Virtual Skills Group and program work queue match (e.g. “OAS VSG” will be for tasks in OAS work queues). Note: The following work queues are not used to manage workload and therefore not monitored. Do not forward tasks to the following work queues: Application Ready For Determination Work Queue Business Expertise FR Business Expertise EN Call Back Requests Core Online Application Received Work Queue SP Integrity L1 SP L1 Western IO Case Processing Queue Atlantic IO Case Processing Queue Withdrawal Request Created Work Queue Service Canada Error Handling for Processing CLIENT MULTI-MATCH NOTIFICATION Service Canada Work Queue BDM SP L2 Communication Failed In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the top right of the detailed task tab and select Forward... . The Forward Task window opens. Determine if the task is being forwarded to a user or work queue: To forward this task to a user: Select User from the Forward To drop-down menu. Click the magnifying glass icon under Forward To to search for the user. The User Search window opens. Enter the user's name in the First Name and Last Name fields and click Search . The user(s) will display under Search Results . Click Select under Action . The user's name will display under Forward To . To forward this task to a work queue: Select Work Queue from the Forward To drop-down menu. Click the magnifying glass icon under Forward To to search for the user. The Select Work Queue window opens. Enter the work queue name in the Name field and click Search . The work queue(s) will display under Search Results . Click Selection under Action . The work queue's name will display under Forward To . Enter comments in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Save . H2 Exp-coll: Complete a task In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the right top of the detailed task tab and select Complete… . A Close Task pop-up window appears to confirm your decision. Click Yes to close the task. Note: Many tasks will close automatically once their specific criteria are met. Others need to be manually closed. H2 Exp-coll: Defer a task A user may want to defer a task when waiting for additional information, or a specific action needs to be completed before a user can action the task. A deferred task will remain in a user's Inbox and move into the My Deferred Tasks page. The time worked will be automatically stopped upon deferral. Note: The task must be in the Work Started section of Open Tasks. In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the top right of the detailed task tab and select Defer… . A Defer Task pop-up window appears to confirm your decision. Enter or select the date under Restart Date . Enter comments to explain why the task is deferred in the Comment field. Click Save . H2 Exp-coll: Make a task Available This task action makes the task available to the previous assignee. The user will no longer see the task in their My Open Tasks list. A user may want to make a task available if they identify that this task cannot be completed by them, and that it should be allocated to the previous assignee to complete. A task that is made available will be unreserved from the user and be allocated to the previous assignee (individual or work queue). In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Open Tasks , click the task's hyperlink under Subject . The task details open in a new tab. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the top right of the detailed task tab and select Make Available… . A Make Tasks Available pop-up window appears to confirm your decision. Enter comments to explain why the task is deferred in the Comment field. Click Save . A task that is made available will be unreserved from the user and be allocated to the previous assignee. This could be another user or a work queue. H2 Exp-coll: Reserving tasks When a user is working on one or more existing tasks associated with a prospect person, person, or case, the user may identify additional tasks on the target. In this case, the user should consider reserving the task with the following guidelines: Is the task(s) currently available to reserve? Do I have the required Skill Type(s) to complete the task(s)? If a user recognizes that the task is available and they have the required Skill Type(s) to complete the task, the user should reserve the task if their availability and language (oral and written) permits it. In Cúram, go to the client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Determine where you are attempting to reserve the task from: To reserve the task on the Person Evidence Case: Remain on the Person Evidence Case. To reserve the task on an Application Case: Click the Cases and Applications tab. Click Applications on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click the hyperlink in front of the case in the Reference column. To reserve the task the task on an Integrated Case: Click the Cases and Applications tab. Click Applications on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click the hyperlink in front of the case in the Reference column. Click Tasks on the navigation bar. Click Add to My Tasks on the page menu. Add to My Tasks window will open. Click the task(s) you are reserving to yourself. These tasks will now be available in your Inbox. Enter the comments in the Comments field. Click Save . H2 Exp-coll: Restart a deferred task A user may want to restart a task if they need to restart it prior to the restart date. Only a task that has been deferred can be restarted. This task action does not apply to tasks that have used the Bring Forward functionality. In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Under My Deferred Tasks , click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu at the end of a task that you want to restart. Click Restart... . The Restart Task window opens. Enter any notes in the Comment field if applicable. Click Save . The task will appear under the My Open Tasks tab. H2 Exp-coll: Transferring a Person or a Case When a user makes an update to a client's specific evidence, such as residence or address, Cúram will automatically reflect the changes in the client's Office of Control (OCON). The Office of Control (OCON) evidence can be found, and reviewed on the client's person evidence case, under Active Evidence . Additionally, a task is generated indicating that the Office of Control has been updated, and to transfer the physical file to the correct Office of Control. This task will be assigned to the OCON that generated the task. Once this task is reserved to a user either through the user reserving the task to themselves, or it being reserved to a user through auto-allocation, the user will reserve the client's tasks to the appropriate work queue based on the client's updated OCON. This would include transfers between OAS Domestic and International Operations (IO), and regional transfers. In Cúram, go to the client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Determine where you are attempting to forward the tasks from: To forward the task(s) to the appropriate work queue from an Application Case: Click the Cases and Applications tab. Click Applications on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click the hyperlink in front of the case in the Reference column. To forward the task(s) to the appropriate work queue from an Application Case: Click the Cases and Applications tab. Click Cases on the page group navigation bar on the left. Identify the Old Age Security case. Click the hyperlink in front of the case in the Reference column. To forward the task(s) to the appropriate work queue from the Prospect Person / Person: Remain on the Prospect Person / Person page. Click Tasks on the navigation bar. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu on the task you are attempting to forward. If you are transferring a task between OAS Domestic and IO, go to Step 5 . If you are transferring a task between regions, including transfers between IO offices, go to Step 9 . Click Edit Task . The Edit Task window opens. Update the Skill Type to the corresponding OAS Domestic or IO Virtual Skill Group (e.g. if the current Virtual Skill Group is OAS-NC-01 and you are transferring to IO, update the Virtual Skill Group to IO-NC-01 ). Note: For Skill Type titles and descriptions, refer to the User skill types (Virtual Skill Group – VSG) and descriptions section below. Click Save . The Edit Task window closes. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu on the task you are attempting to forward. Click Forward . The Forward Task window will open. Click the drop-down menu for Forward To. Click Work Queue . Click the magnifying glass. The Select Work Queue window opens. Enter in part of, or the full name of the work queue. Tip: In most cases, the suffix part should remain the same, with the prefix changing. If a task is currently in OAS Domestic, reserved to OAS-ATL-Processing, and must be moved to the Atlantic International Operations Processing queue, the work queue will be IO-ATL-Processing. Click the Select hyperlink of the work queue. The Select Work Queue window will close, and you will return to the Forward Task window. Click Save . Note: This must be done for all the tasks that must be forwarded. Once the user has forwarded the client's task(s) to the appropriate work queue, the user can complete the transfer file task. Note: If there is a need to move the physical file, follow your existing process. H2 Exp-coll: Handling Tasks With No Linked Person or Prospect Person If an agent receives a task that is not linked to a Person or Prospect Person in Cúram, and the Person or Prospect Person cannot be identified using the supporting information, links, and attachments in the task, a ticket must be raised to Operations to retrieve the original PWS task for the agent. Based on the details in the original PWS task, the agent should navigate to Cúram to identify the client and continue the related workload, or if the work is no longer applicable, update the task status to complete. If an agent must stop, defer, bring forward, reallocate, forward, or make the work available, the agent can add a comment with additional information to the unlinked task using the instructions found in the Add comments to a task section above. H2 Exp-coll: Work queues A work queue is a central repository that organizes, holds, and tracks the tasks that need to be completed within the system. Work queues are used to manage and monitor user-created, or system-generated workload. There are two types of work queues: automatic work queues and manual work queues. Team members will only be subscribed to manual work queues. Team leads will be subscribed to both automatic and manual work queues to monitor workload, however, team leads will only subscribe team members to manual queues. Automatic work queues are used to hold tasks that can be automatically assigned by the system to users. Manual work queues are used to manage specific tasks that require manual intervention for allocation. A campaign work queue is a work queue created a result of an organization-planned activity or an event. It is organized with the purpose to complete an identified set of tasks by a specific group of staff members. Work queues have been configured specifically for Old Age Security (OAS). In addition to automatic and manual work queue configurations, work queues are defined by region and purpose. Each region has a respective automatic and manual work queue Additionally, there are different work queues based on region (region or national), type of workload (migrated from legacy or generated in Cúram), and work queues by business units. Table 9 – Types of work queues Type of work queue Description Work queue example National work queues Represents a work queue with tasks allocated irrespective of region. One-Workload-Processing One-Workload- PWS -Migrated Regional work queues Represents a work queue with tasks allocated respective of region. OAS-WT-Processing OAS-QC-Processing PWS (legacy) work queues Represents a work queue holding tasks migrated from PWS . OAS-ATL- PWS -Migrated-Automated New task (Cúram-generated) work queues Represents a work queue holding tasks generated by Cúram. OAS-ATL-Processing Work queues by business units Represents a work queue for a specific business unit for their own specific workload. These are part of other types of work queues. OAS-QC-Processing CSB-QC ISB-OAS-NHQ CC-WT-Pensions IO-WT-Processing OAS-Foreign-Direct-Deposit Incarceration-Processing Error work queue Represents a work queue for tasks that fail to be automatically sent to the appropriate regional work queue. The failure is due to the appropriate metadata not being captured on the document with a scan location of Virtual . OAS-INTAKE-ERROR-TASKS H2 Exp-coll: User skill types (Virtual Skill Group – VSG) and descriptions Table 10 – User skill types (virtual skill group – VSG) and descriptions Skill Type Title Description OAS-Core-01 Incoming Mail Intake of all incoming mail, and classification of the document types related to OAS program. Registering new clients in Cúram and ensuring attachments are assigned to the correct Person or Case level on the client record. Data capturing of all OAS/GIS/ ALW / ALWS applications into the IEG script in Cúram. OAS-Core-02 Core Work activities related to maintenance and client inquiries for the OAS pension and GIS/ ALW / ALWS benefits delegated at the CR03 level. OAS-NC-01 OAS/GIS Level 1 Applications and work activities related to the eligibility and entitlement of the OAS pension without periods of residence outside of Canada or periods less than six months outside of Canada. Applications and work activities related to the eligibility and entitlement of GIS benefits. OAS-NC-02 ALW / ALWS Level 1 Applications and work activities related to the eligibility and entitlement of ALW / ALWS benefits. OAS-NC-03 Renewal Applications and work activities related to the renewal of GIS/ ALW / ALWS benefits.
