Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05502&amp;cid=CAT-02019</reference><title>Maximum Deduction Amount and Deduction Payment History—Edit and View in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with the steps to manually edit the maximum deduction amount and view the deduction payment history in Cúram. What you need to know A deduction is an amount withheld from a payment. The maximum deduction amount is the amount that can be deducted to recover overpayments, penalties, and interest from a pay-run (gross to net). Note: The maximum deduction amount it is calculated based on the current policy rules. The CPP benefit entitlement is excluded from the calculation. The maximum deduction amount will be stored on the Product Delivery Case and displayed on the Overpayment Case for reference. The maximum deduction amount is not associated to a single deduction. It is the common deduction amount that is linked to all active overpayment, penalty, and interest deductions. The maximum deduction amount is equal to the recovery rate that will be withheld from benefit payments to repay monies owed to the Department. Note: The maximum deduction amount is applicable to departmental liabilities and is not used for third party liabilities. If the Auto Calculate box is checked, Cúram will auto calculate and create the maximum deduction amount after the following trigger events: Note: If you manually edit the maximum deduction amount, you must make sure you uncheck the Auto Calculate box to have it applied. Overpayment update triggers An Overpayment Case (manual Overpayment Case or Payment Correction Case) is activated. There is a change in future OAS eligibility and entitlement. An Overpayment Case is suspended or unsuspended. Note: When an Overpayment Case is suspended or unsuspended, Cúram will deactivate or active the associated deduction and recalculate the maximum deduction amount. Penalty and interest triggers A new penalty or interest is added and there is no existing maximum deduction amount. A new penalty or interest is added for a current and future existing maximum deduction amount. A new penalty or interest initial liability amount is updated, and the new amount is more than the running outstanding liability balance, the current and future maximum deduction amount. Manually triggers You manually edit a maximum deduction amount line item (recovery amount or recovery percentage) and the Auto Calculate box is unchecked. Note: You must clear the Auto Calculate box to have the manually entered maximum deduction amount used for the deduction by Cúram. The deduction will start 60 days after the activation of debt or the maximum deduction amount. Note: These triggers update existing overpayment(s) and deduction(s) by recalculating the maximum deduction amount. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: View deduction payment history In Cúram, go to the person's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Cases and Applications tab. Click Cases in the page group navigation bar on the left. The list of available cases appears. Click the Old Age Security Program Benefit case hyperlink. The Old Age Security Program Benefit case opens. Click the Financials tab. Click Deductions in the page group navigation bar on the left. The list of available records appears. Click the History tab under Deductions. The list of recovered amounts displays. H2 Exp-coll: Manually edit the maximum deduction amount In Cúram, go to the person's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Cases and Applications tab. Click Cases in the page group navigation bar on the left. The list of available cases appears. Click the Old Age Security Program Benefit case hyperlink. The Old Age Security Program Benefit case opens. Click the Financials tab. Click Maximum Deduction Amount in the page group navigation bar on the left. The list of recovered amounts displays. Click the Edit at the end of the recovery amount line. The Edit Maximum Deduction Amount window opens. Enter the following details in the Edit Maximum Deduction Amount window: Table 1—Fields and Directions under the Edit Maximum Deduction Amount window Field Direction Change Reason Mandatory Select one of the following options: Hardship Hardship Discontinued Client Request User Error Other Note: If you selected Other , enter the comments in the Comments field. Start Date Mandatory Verify the date under Start Date . If the date is correct, leave the field as is. If the date is incorrect, select the correct date. Recovery Amount Enter the recovery amount. Note: The amount entered may be more than the regular monthly value if the client's benefits are paid on a non-standard payment frequency. (Gross to Net cannot adjust fixed value deductions to account for multiple months of payments, e.g. if the client is getting a semi-annual payment and we want to collect 100.00 per month starting in January, the deduction value needs to be input as 600.00 (100 x 6) so that when the payment is issued in June, we take 600.00 not 100.00). Note: You can use either the Recovery Amount field or the Recovery Percentage field when manually editing the maximum deduction amount. The Auto Calculate box must be unchecked for the changes to take effect. Recovery Percentage Enter the recovery percentage. Note: You can use either the Recovery Amount field or the Recovery Percentage field when manually editing the maximum deduction amount. The Auto Calculate box must be unchecked for the changes to take effect. Auto Calculate Deselect the box. Enter the comments in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Save . The Edit Maximum Deduction Amount screen closes and Cúram will update the maximum deduction amount. Note: The deduction will start 60 days after the activation of debt or the maximum deduction amount. Note: You will be required to add details of the changes in ITRDS notes. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05503&amp;cid=CAT-02017</reference><title>Death Details Evidence — Edit in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with steps to add a date of death to birth and death details evidence in Cúram. What you need to know When a death notification is received, the date of death must be added to the birth and death details evidence as soon as possible because it will impact any OAS pension and benefits the client is currently receiving. Once the date of death is added or updated on the birth and death details evidence and activated, Cúram will run a reassessment to ensure that the account is in balance. If, at anytime during the reassessment process, the account is not in balance, the system is unable to perform actions automatically, or when there is a conflicting date of death received or the existing date of death is removed via the ITRDS Interface, a task will be generated for manual review. As part of the reassessment process, Cúram will automatically: Update the spouse's Marital Relationship evidence to Surviving Spouse/Common Law Partner , if applicable. If the system is unable to update the Marital Relationship evidence of the spouse, it will create a task for the processing centre to review the account; Send the Surviving Spouse OAS Rate Change (ISP-3393) letter outlining the new monthly benefit, if monetary changes are detected for the spouse; Send the Client has died outside of Canada (ISS-2388) letter, if the death occurred outside of Canada; and Generate a task to review the account if there are any existing overpayment or underpayment and/or any new overpayment or underpayment generated because of the date of death (e.g. the date of death was reported late). Note: If the date of death evidence is not activated, no reassessments are performed. Instead, the date of death is placed in an In Edit status pending verification and activation. Therefore, to stop a client's benefits, the death evidence must be activated. Date of Death received via ITRDS The ITRDS interface will send a Date of Death notification to Cúram when proof of death is provided from source CPP or source SIR-PRV-C . Once the date of death evidence is updated in Cúram, it is automatically activated, and a reassessment is performed. Note: If proof of death is not provided for source CPP , then the date of death will still be sent to Cúram but the evidence will remain in an In Edit status until it is manually activated. No reassessment occurs until the evidence is activated. Since the ITRDS Interface automatically activates the date of death evidence in Cúram, there are certain scenarios where reports will be generated to ensure additional actions are taken on the account. The gaps listed below have been placed on the enhancement backlog and are scheduled to be built in future Cúram iterations. Until permanent fixes are developed, the following workarounds have been established for each scenario: Table 1—Development Gaps and Workarounds Gap Workaround The client is suspended in Cúram for the following reasons: Cannot locate ISB Request OAS-RI Non-Filer Other A report will identify any clients that have a date of death and where the client is suspended for one of the reasons listed in the Gap column. The report will be used to create tasks to notify users that a date of death has been received for the client. The client is under investigation by the Integrity Services Branch (ISB) and is in-pay for benefits A report will identify any clients that have a date of death and are under ISB investigation while in pay for benefits. The report will be used to create tasks to notify ISB. The client is incarcerated A report will identify any clients that have a date of death and are incarcerated. The report will be used to create tasks to notify the Incarceration team. There is an existing date of death in Cúram and a new date of death with a different month/year is interfaced from ITRDS A report will be generated to identify any instance where an existing date of death in Cúram has been replaced with a new date of death from ITRDS . The report will be used to create a task so that a user can review the account to ensure the date of death is accurate. There is an existing date of death in Cúram and ITRDS removes the date of death A report will be generated to identify any instance where an existing Cúram date of death was removed via ITRDS . The report will be used to create tasks so that a user can review the account to ensure that the removal was appropriate. Surviving Spouse OAS Rate Change (ISP-3393) letter The automation of the Surviving Spouse OAS Rate Change (ISP-3393) letter cannot be performed by Cúram in the 2 following scenarios: This letter is OAS pension/ GIS specific and does not cover situations where the ALW benefit is converted to the ALWS benefit. This letter is only generated when there is a monetary impact to the surviving spouse. However, it also needs to be generated any time there is a reassessment under a different rate table. To mitigate these risks, a report will be generated to identify any of the above situations. The report will be used to create tasks so that a user can manually send any appropriate letters as needed. Migrated Client records Updated For client accounts that have been migrated with a date of death, the Birth and Death details will be in the In-Edit state and will need to be verified. This can be done following the steps in the Add proof and Apply death details evidence sections under the What you need to do in the Step by Step tab. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: Edit death details evidence In Cúram, go to the person's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Evidence tab. Click Active Evidence in the left sidebar. The Active Evidence window opens. Click the ( &gt; ) toggle icon to show the Birth and Death Details evidence. Click Edit on the right side of the evidence. The Edit Birth and Death Details window opens. Enter the following information in the Death section of the Edit Birth and Death Details window: Table 1—Fields and Directions under the Death section of the Edit Birth and Death Details Window Field Direction Date of Death Select the date of death from the calendar. Date Notified of Death Select the date the Department was notified of the client's death from the calendar. Country of Death Select the country where the person died from the Country of Death drop-down menu. Presumptive Death Select one of the following from the Presumptive Death drop-down menu, if applicable: No Yes Received From Select one of the following options from the Received From drop-down menu: Client - Reported Foreign Government Representative Note: You must always select Representative unless the death is reported via Foreign Government . Received from Country If Foreign Government is chosen in the Received From drop-down, select the country the notification was received from in the Received from Country drop-down menu. Note: If the date of death is from a restricted country (i.e. Japan, Jamaica, or the United States of America), then the date of death must be captured under the restricted date of death evidence on the Foreign Engagement Case. This information can only be captured by an International Operations user). Mode of Receipt If Foreign Government is chosen in the Received From drop-down, select one of the following options from the Mode of Receipt drop-down menu: Liaison Certified on Application Enter the comments in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Save . The Active Evidence window opens. H2 Exp-coll: Add proof Updated Updated Note: The Item for Verification name will be the same for a date of birth and date of death when both appear as outstanding verifications, they are not duplicates. If proof of date of birth was not previously added on a migrated account, you will need to add proof to complete the verification. In Cúram, go to the client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Evidence tab. The Evidence Dashboard opens. Click Verifications in the left sidebar. The Verifications window opens. Click Add Proof . The Add Proof window opens. Enter the following details in the Add Proof window: Note: The Provided By section should represent who provided the date of death information. What you need to know Clients can submit a request for reconsideration anytime they disagree with a decision made on their case. The client must submit a request for reconsideration within 90 days of the date of the decision letter from Service Canada. The request for reconsideration can be submitted using the Request for Reconsideration of an Old Age Security Decision (ISP-3134) form or online through the client portal. Note: You must not authorize any benefit application when there is an open reconsideration for the client. When a client submits a request for reconsideration from the client portal, a request for reconsideration task is created in the appropriate work queue. Cúram automatically displays a corresponding reconsideration flag on the context panel for the Person or Prospect Person and associated case for the client. When a written request for reconsideration is processed, a task is created in Cúram that shows the client's SIN or Cúram Reference Number, the client's name, and Request for Reconsideration for the Type. The request is also listed as an attachment under the Contacts tab. You must manually add a flag to the client's profile to indicate it is under reconsideration. When the reconsideration is closed, you must remove the flag. When there is a reconsideration on an account with an overpayment that resulted from the decision the client is requesting the reconsideration for, recovery action must be deferred if it has not been initiated. If recovery has already been initiated, then it must be suspended until the outcome of the reconsideration, or the appeal is known. You should manually de-activate a payment correction or overpayment (manual) case deduction for a departmental liability. Note: If there is an existing overpayment on the client's account (i.e. misrepresentation or fraud that was carried over), the overpayment is not suspended and remains active. What you need to know Correspondence (i.e. letters) are created in Cúram to communicate with a client or a verified third party on a Person record, Application Case, Integrated Case and/or a Foreign Engagement Case. If you cannot find the correspondence template in Cúram, updated versions are available on the Forms and Letters page of the KMT. You must search for NATS letters temporarily stored on the KMT before searching in NATS. There are 3 types of letters being generated out of Cúram with the Corporate Correspondence Tool (CCT): bulk letters; on demand letters; and manual letters. Table 1—Types of letters in the CCT Type of letter Description Bulk letters Bulk correspondence (also known as "bulk letters") are high volume letters sent to clients on a set schedule. This schedule can be daily, weekly, monthly or yearly, depending on the type of letter. Client data in Cúram determines who will be scheduled to receive each type of scheduled bulk letter. Bulk correspondence is generated automatically by the CCT with a data file created by Cúram through a system process and is sent to the CCT to produce the correspondence. Clients are selected to receive each type of scheduled bulk letter based on changes made to their personal or case record. The list of clients who meet the criteria for each bulk letter is created by Cúram and sent to the CCT to create the letters. Each type of bulk correspondence has a specific template. New Cúram will automatically prevent the generation of bulk letters for clients marked as duplicates. On demand letters On demand letters include 5 specific letters: Application for the Allowance or Allowance for the Survivor (ISS-3008) Application for the Guaranteed Income Supplement with Statement of Income (ISS-3025B/ISB-3026) Statement of Income for the GIS , the ALW or ALWS (ISS-3026) OAS Cancellation of Waiver of Application by Minister (ISS-8418B/ISP3550) Client has died outside of Canada (ISS-2388) These system-generated letters are printed in the manual nightly batch printing process. Manual correspondence Manual correspondence generation can be submitted for nightly bulk printing. This allows the system to generate bulk correspondence for a targeted group of clients or recipients when required. For every letter created (bulk, on demand or manual), a correspondence tracking number and a communication record is created in Cúram. Note: The client's mailing address and preferred language must be set in the Person record to be able to create correspondence. All correspondence is displayed on the Person record, but only the correspondence specific to a case are created and displayed on the Case record. To create a letter, you must specify the recipients of the correspondence, select a template to use, and complete all mandatory data/selections and/or all required options. A pop-up interface with the CCT is used to complete the template and generate the correspondence. Refer to Confirmed Priority ISS Template Titles – 2024-07-17 (Excel, 44 KB) Download link for a current list of available templates. Once the correspondence template has been opened, a hyperlink is created based on the correspondence tracking number and work item generated for that letter. Note: The hyperlink is only enabled if the communication status is set to Draft , Submitted , Sent or Returned . If required, you can submit an incomplete application to enable you to generate correspondence from the Application Case. H2 Exp-coll: Central printing Central Printing is where the bulk printing occurs, where manual letters would be produced in a nightly batch. This is the default method unless the letter does not meet the requirements for bulk printing. The process of centrally printing correspondence is available for most scenarios. A letter must not be greater than 5 physical pages (shows as 10 pages in a PDF due to double sided (duplex) printing) including pages from attachments added to the letter. The letter and attachment must be the same page size (i.e. 8.5x11 inches and 8.5x14 inches are distinct sizes and cannot be combined for central printing). The size is based on the page size of the template, not the size of the attachment. Once this letter has been submitted for printing, Cúram will change the communication status from Submitted to Sent , when the print file is sent to the print provider. H2 Exp-coll: Local printing Local printing is used when requirements are not met for the nightly batch requirements. If the letter is more than 5 physical pages duplexed, the CCT will remove the letter from the print file. Cúram sets the communication status to Submitted Oversize after the nightly print job has been completed. Once the process is completed, a task to manually print the letter is generated and assigned back to the Department's representative who created the letter or the processing work queue for task assignment. The task includes the correspondence tracking number. Note: The option to print locally is available if you already know the correspondence is oversized to avoid any delay in getting the letter printed. When using local print, you must check the Confirm Delivery to ensure Cúram changes the status from Draft or Submitted to Sent . H2 Exp-coll: Communication status Cúram will change the Communication Status to Sent for any central printing letters. Some of the following statuses can be changed manually. The following status are available in Cúram: Table 2—Available Communication status Status Description Draft The Draft status is displayed once the template has been selected and all mandatory data is populated and Edit after Submit has been selected to open the template. This will create the hyperlink to the letter in Cúram, along with the Correspondence Tracking Number for this letter. Submitted The Submitted status is a transition state that indicates a letter has been submitted for printing and is awaiting the delivery options that are associated with the letter to complete. For central printing, it will show in this state until the nightly batch is completed. For local printing, this status will show before Confirm Delivery has been selected. Sent The Sent status is displayed automatically by Cúram when a manual or system-generated correspondence has successfully been bulk printed, or when a manual correspondence has been locally printed (once the user confirms delivery). Submitted Oversized The Submitted Oversized status is displayed by Cúram when the manual nightly print job has failed because a letter is over the 5-page maximum allowed by Central Print (manual only). A task will be generated and assigned back to the processing work queue for task assignment. Misdirected The Misdirected status is manually updated in Cúram when correspondence is sent to a wrong recipient and is potentially a privacy breach. This status removes access to the correspondence in the vault by removing the hyperlink to the letter. This status can be manually changed. Returned The Returned status is used when the correspondence is returned. This status is updated manually in Cúram. Once the status is updated, a task ("TASK-07 Review nature of absence evidence") will be generated. This status can be manually changed. Void The Void status is used when the correspondence has been identified as incorrect. This status removes access to the correspondence in the vault by removing the hyperlink to the letter. This status can be manually changed. Intercepted The Intercepted status will display in Cúram when the request to pull a letter from a bulk or nightly batch file was successfully pulled before it was mailed to the client. Only Central Print can change this status. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: Create correspondence in a client's record In Cúram, go to the client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click Contacts . Click Communications in the page group navigation bar on the left. Click Create Correspondence . The Step 1: Create Correspondence tab of the Create Correspondence window opens. Enter the following information in the Step 1: Create Correspondence tab of the Capture Correspondence window: Table 3—Fields and directions for the Step 1: Create Correspondence tab of the Capture Correspondence window Field Direction Client is Correspondent Check the Client is Correspondent box if the client is the correspondent. Note: If the client is the correspondent, do not populate the other fields in the window. Third Party Contact for Client (Verified) Select the name of the correspondent from the Third Party Contact for Client (Verified) drop-down menu if the correspondent for the communication is registered in Cúram as the client's third-party contact. Note: If a letter needs to be cc'd to a verified third-party contact, select the client or verified third party as the main correspondent. Then, in the Select Recipient – CC section, select the valid third party from the Third Party Contact for Client (Verified) drop-down menu. Contact for Client (Un-Verified) Select the name of the correspondent from the Contact for Client (Un-Verified) drop-down menu if the correspondent for the communication is registered in Cúram. Note: This option should be rarely used. A client may have an unverified contact in rare circumstances (e.g. if a client dies or becomes incapable, insufficient documentation may be received by an unverified third party). In cases like this when further documentation is required to verify the contact or additional communication is necessary, an unverified contact is added to communicate with the unverified individual. When an unverified contact is selected, the client information is locked down in the template to prevent unauthorized access to client information. The client information will not be added to the letter (client ID, any specific client details), it will be important to ensure you can still send that letter with the missing data. Click Next . The Step 2: Search Template tab opens. Enter the information in the Step 2: Search Template tab as follows: Table 4—Fields and Directions under the Step 2: Search Template tab of the Create Correspondence window Field Direction Templates ID/Name Enter the name or ID of the template in the Template ID/Name field, if known (e.g. 8584, ISS-8584 or Direct Deposit). Click Search . Note: The Template Category and Template Sub-Category do not need to be completed if the Template ID/Name is known. Template Category Select a category from the Template Category drop-down menu. Note: You must select an option in both the Template Category and the Template Sub-Category fields. The template sub-category is dependent on the type of category you select in the Template Category field. Template Sub-Category Select a sub-category from the Template Sub-Category drop-down menu. Note: You must select an option in both the Template Category and the Template Sub-Category fields. The Template Sub-category field is dependent on the type of category you select in the Template Category field. Click Search . The search results appear under Results (Number of Items: X). Click Select next to the appropriate correspondence template. The Submit Correspondence tab opens. Confirm the details are correct and select Edit after Submit from the options: Note: If the details are not correct, return to the previous screen to correct the information by clicking Previous . If you want to cancel the correspondence, click Cancel to close the pop-up window. Table 5 — Fields and Directions under the options within the Submit Correspondence tab. Field Direction Edit after submit Select this option if you want to edit the letter in Corporate Correspondence Tool (CCT). It is best practice to select this option for every correspondence created. View after submit Select this option if you do not want to edit the letter. It will appear in CCT in view mode only. Note: Avoid this option as all manual letters have at least one selection within, which will cause errors with this option. Click Submit . The CCT opens in a new window. Go to the Generate a letter in the Corporate Correspondence Tool section below. H2 Exp-coll: Create correspondence in a case In Cúram, access the client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Determine where to create the correspondence. Navigate to the Cases and Applications from the group navigation: To create correspondence on an Application Case: Click Applications on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click the hyperlink in front of the case in the Reference column. To create correspondence on an Integrated Case or Foreign Engagement Case: Click Cases on the page group navigation bar on the left. Click the hyperlink in front of the case in the Reference column. Click Contacts . Click Communications in the page group navigation bar on the left. Click Create Correspondence . The Step 1: Create Correspondence tab of the Create Correspondence window opens. Enter the following information in the Step 1: Create Correspondence tab of the Capture Correspondence window: Table 6—Fields and directions for the Step1: Create Correspondence tab of the Capture Correspondence window Field Direction Case Participant Select the client from the Case Participant drop-down menu if the client is the correspondent. Third Party Contact for Client (Verified) Select the name of the correspondent from the Third Party Contact for Client (Verified) drop-down menu if the correspondent for the communication is registered in Cúram as the client's third-party contact. Note: If a letter needs to be cc'd to a verified third-party contact, select the client or verified third party as the main correspondence. Then, in the Select Recipient – CC section , select the valid third party from the Third Party Contact for Client (Verified) drop-down menu. Contact for Client (Un-Verified) Select the name of the correspondent from the Contact for Client (Un-Verified) drop-down menu if the correspondent for the communication is registered in Cúram. Note: This option is very rarely used. A client may have an unverified contact in rare circumstances (e.g. if a client dies or becomes incapable, insufficient documentation may be received by an unverified third party). In cases like this when further documentation is required to verify the contact or additional communication is necessary, an unverified contact is added to communicate with the unverified individual. When an unverified contact is selected, the client information is locked down in Cúram. The client information will not be added to the letter. Click Next . The Step 2: Search Template tab opens. Enter the information in the Step 2: Search Template tab as follows: Table 7—Field and Direction under the Step 2: Search Template tab of the Create Correspondence window Field Direction Templates ID/Name Enter the name or ID of the template in the Template ID/Name field, if known (e.g. 8584, ISS-8584, Direct Deposit). Click Search . Note: The Template Category and Template Sub-Category do not need to be completed if the Template ID/Name is known. Note: Avoid this option as all manual letters have at least one selection within, which will cause errors with this option. Click Submit . The CCT opens in a new window. Go to the Generate a letter in the corporate correspondence tool section below. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05506&amp;cid=CAT-02015</reference><title>Team and Workload Management in Cúram (Action)</title><video_link>['https://014gc.sharepoint.com/sites/95530/Howto%20Clips/How-to%20Clips/Processing/Team%20Leads/Workload%20Management%20in%20C%C3%BAram/How%20to%20Self%20Subscribe,%20Unsubscribe,%20and%20View%20a%20Work%20Queue.mp4', 'https://014gc.sharepoint.com/sites/95530/Howto%20Clips/How-to%20Clips/Processing/Team%20Leads/Workload%20Management%20in%20C%C3%BAram/How%20to%20Subscribe%20and%20Unsubscribe%20a%20Team%20Member.mp4']</video_link><video_name>['How to Self Subscribe, Unsubscribe, and View a Work Queue', 'How to Subscribe and Unsubscribe a Team Member']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with the steps to monitor and manage your team and workload in Cúram as a team leader. What you need to know Users that are team leads will have a team-lead application banner, including Home, Team and Workloads, and Inbox subsections in Cúram. The Team and Workloads subsection includes two supervisor-specific workspaces: Supervisor User Workspace ; and Supervisor Work Queue Workspace . Supervisor User Workspace The Supervisor User Workspace provides the ability for team leads to view, monitor and maintain workloads for users that report to them. This includes viewing users' tasks that are Assigned , Open , and Deferred . Team leads are also able to forward and reallocate tasks from a user to another user or work queue, respectively. This is available under My Users , located under the "My Users" header on the Shortcuts panel. From the My Users page, team leads can view the list of all users reporting to them and see a count of their reserved or assigned tasks as a dashboard. It also allows the team lead to quickly view the prioritized skills, post training monitoring skills and language for their user. Team leads can search for other users in the system to manage their workload. This may be used when covering for another supervisor or supporting a team lead and managing their team. Team leads also have 2 supervisor-specific searches: Supervisor User Search ; and Supervisor Task Search. Team leads can search for other users in the system to manage their workload. This may be used when covering for another supervisor or supporting a team lead and managing their team. Team leads can navigate into a specific user's workspace to manage their workload. A team lead can use the Supervisor User Search to navigate to a user's workspace who is directly on their team, or of a team they are supporting. Alternatively, if the user is a team member, the team lead can use the My Users list and navigate to the user's workspace directly through the hyperlinked Name of the team member . Supervisor Work Queue Workspace My Work Queues is the list of work queues that the team lead is monitoring. The team lead can subscribe to any work queue they wish to monitor. This list displays the number of tasks assigned to each of the listed work queues, allowing the user to understand the current outstanding workload. This can be found in My Work Queues, under My Users in the shortcuts panel. The Subscribed Work Queues tab lists the work queues subscribed by various organizational objects to which the team lead is associated to. For OAS, this is limited to subscription to users. The Work Queue Workspace allows team leads the ability to view, monitor and maintain workloads within the queue. It also provides essential information about a work queue. Within this workspace, you can find the following details regarding a work queue: Work Queue Owner; User Subscription Allowed: Serves as a reference to identify whether users can subscribe themselves to that work queue; Sensitivity level: For a user to add themselves to a particular work queue, their sensitivity level must match or exceed that of the work queue. Currently, all work queues have a sensitivity level set to 1, indicating the minimum requirement for user subscription; Users subscribed; Assigned tasks; and Reserved tasks. Subscribing to a work queue will allow a team lead to access a work queue's workload. A team lead should only subscribe to a work queue that they wish to monitor and to manage the users that should be subscribed to or unsubscribed from the work queue. Team leads can subscribe to work queues that are either automated or manual and align to their region or business unit. Note: Team members should only be subscribed to the manual work queues that correspond to their specific program (OAS or International Operations (IO)), business line (Processing, Citizen Services Branch, Integrity Services Branch (ISB), Call Centre) and region (ATL, QC, ON, WT, NHQ). However, some staff members (e.g. team leads, regional and national workload managers) may subscribe to additional work queues (manual and automated) based on functional requirements and organizational workload strategies. If a team lead determines that a task must be sent to a CPP team for further processing, a team lead should use the existing procedures to create a PWS item related to CPP. If there is no additional work to be completed in Cúram, the task can be completed. New All incoming paper documents (including applications) designated in the Pension Trusted Digital Repository (PTDR) with a scan location of Virtual are automatically re-routed in Cúram to the appropriate regional queue. Team leads and OAS administrators must monitor the workload in the “OAS-INTAKE-ERROR-TASKS” manual work queue to identify tasks that fail to be directed to the appropriate work queue through this automated process. Tasks are automatically allocated to the appropriate regional work queue based on the PTDR metadata. For more information on the work queues, refer to section Work Queues . For more information on the countries for which each IO office is responsible for, refer to Foreign Benefits - International Social Security Agreements Countries . You can access the work queue workspace under your subscription to manage the tasks in that work queue. Each work queue workspace has 3 tabs: Table 1-Tabs under the Work Queue Workspace Tab Details Home The Home tab displays the list of subscribed users of the work queue. Assigned Tasks The Assigned Tasks tab allows you to search for available tasks in the work queue that have not been forwarded or reserved to anyone. These tasks can be reserved to a processing team member from this tab. Note: The Assigned Task page will display tasks that are assigned to the user but not yet reserved to the user. As tasks are automatically reserved to the user when assignment occurs, this list will not display tasks except the ones that existed in this list from R1. Reserved Tasks The Reserved Tasks tab displays your processing team members' reserved tasks that are in Open and Deferred status. Note: This only applies to team leads. Note: By default, tasks are sorted by importance. User can re-sort as required using column headers. In the Inbox tab under a user's Tasks tab, tasks are segmented into 5 specific fields as described below: Table 2-Fields and Descriptions of Task Tab Fields Field Description Assigned Task The Assigned Tasks field is empty by default, unless there is a task listed under the Assigned Tasks category that is not specifically reserved for a particular staff member. In situations where the Assigned Tasks section is empty, the Make Available action will be disabled. All tasks will immediately be sent to Open Tasks and can be moved to Deferred Tasks . My Open Tasks The Open Tasks field displays the tasks split into 2 different sections. The Work Started field shows open tasks where the timer has been started by the team member, and the timer is still running. It only includes tasks where the most recent change type is Work Started and there is no Work Stopped change type after that. The Work Stopped / Work Not Started field displays open tasks where the timer has been stopped by the team member or tasks where the timer has not yet been started. It includes all open tasks for the team member, except for the ones displayed in the Work Started list. My Deferred Tasks The Deferred tasks field displays the tasks reserved to the team member where the task status is Deferred . Allocation Blocking History The Task Allocation Blocking History field provides a comprehensive list of the current, pending and expired allocation blocks. The supervisor can clear active or pending allocation blocks. The Allocation Blocking History page can be found under the Tasks tab in a user's workspace. My Users displays the name of your processing team members and the number of tasks that are reserved for or forwarded to the processing team member. You can also access your processing team member's workspace through My Users . You must be subscribed to a work queue to display the tasks that are in the work queue and to add or remove subscribers. To manage user-subscribed work queues and their associated tasks, you can navigate to the My Work Queues section under the My Users tab in the Shortcuts panel of the Teams and Workload tab. Note: Processing team members should only be subscribed to the manual work queues that correspond to their specific program (OAS or IO), business line (Processing, Citizen Services Branch, ISB, Call Centre) and region (ATL, QC, ON, WT, NHQ). Do not subscribe processing team members to any automated work queues. Once a processing team member is subscribed to a manual work queue, they have access to the tasks and can view them. Unsubscribing them from the manual work queue removes their access. Once subscribed to a manual work queue, a processing team member has the ability to reserve tasks to My Tasks list. The team lead can reserve a task directly from the work queue. H2 Exp-coll: Task statuses All tasks are categorized by 4 statuses: Open On Hold Deferred Completed Note: A task has an Open status when it is created. Tasks can be modified based on the task actions. This includes: Start Work: This task action moves a user's task from the Stopped Work / Work Not Started list to the Started Work list. Stop Work: This task action moves a user's task from the Started Work list to the Stopped Work / Work Not Started list. Add Comment : This task action allows a user to add comments to a task. Edit Task: This task action allows a user to update the category, type, skill type, and priority level of a task. Edit Due / Receipt Date: This task action allows a user to update the due date and receipt date of a task. Bring Forward: This task action allows a user to set the task to On Hold status until the bring forward date. This task will be allocated to the assigned work queue until the Bring Forward Date and will not show in the user's My Tasks list . Once the Bring Forward Date arrives, the system will set the task status back to Open . Make Available: This task action makes the task available to the previous assigned. The user will no longer see the task in their My Open Tasks list. Forward: This task action allows a user to forward a task assigned to them, to another user or work queue. Team leads can forward tasks that are not assigned to them. These tasks can be viewed in the Open Tasks page of the processing user's workspace or in the work queue workspace. Reallocate: This task action allows a user to remove the task from their inbox and re-run the allocation strategy that initially allocated the task at creation. Defer: This task action allows a user to set the task to Deferred status until the restart date. A task is deferred, and the task status is updated to Deferred . It will remain in the user's inbox and move into the My Deferred Tasks page. Restart: This task action allows a user to manually restart a deferred task and return it to the user's My Open Tasks list. Complete: This task action allows a user to update the status of a task to Completed . A task is completed and requires no further action. H2 Exp-coll: Distributing Tasks Note: The following process is only conducted by team leads. For more information, refer to the Forward tasks reserved a team member (Forward Reserved Tasks or Forward) section in the What you need to do section under the Step by Step tab. Note: Team leaders use these functions to reassign an assigned, open or deferred task(s) to another team member or return it to a work queue. Reallocate tasks to a work queue Use the Reallocate function to reallocate currently reserved tasks (open and deferred) to the work queue it was originally assigned by the system. Note: For all tasks that have been data-migrated from PWS directly to a user's inbox, a user's inbox will be the first location that Cúram records the task being reserved to. If a user must "reallocate" tasks from their inbox that was assigned to them and data migrated from PWS , the user should use the forward function to forward the tasks to another work queue. Edit Task Use the Edit function to edit task details. For more information, refer to the Edit Task section in the What you need to do section under the Step by Step tab. Table 5-User Management Situation Direction Add Task Allocation Blocking Use the Allocation Blocking… function to add task allocation blocking for a user.  For more information, refer to the Add task allocation blocking section in the What you need to do section under the Step by Step tab. H2 Exp-coll: Administrator Support There are a few key scenarios where administrator support is required in the Supervisor User Workspace. Firstly, when a team lead is attempting to forward more than 100 tasks in a single transaction, the team lead needs to contact an administrator to complete the batch process request. If you need the batch summary details after the batch is run, the administrator will provide the summary. A manual batch job is required to complete the forwarding of 100 or more tasks. You must submit a ticket to the National Service Desk Internal link to request the scheduling of a batch job. Tasks awaiting the batch job run cannot be manually forwarded. If you have 100 or more tasks that need to be forwarded and reviewed immediately, limit the number of tasks forwarded to 99 or less at a time to allow the forwarding to occur immediately. Secondly, when a team lead navigates to the My Users screen and it displays users that are not on their direct or indirect reporting or missing users, an administrator will need to update the organization unit and position for these users. Thirdly, when a user is added to the system, the user is assigned the following: an organization unit (e.g. ATL SDN Operations Call Centre Team 101) position (e.g. ATL SDN Operations Call Centre Team 10 Lead Position 01) language (English, French, Bilingual) An administrator manages this information from the Administrator Workspace. If a user changes organizations units, positions or acquires another language, an administrator must be contacted to update the user's profile. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do Work queue subscription H2 Exp-coll: Subscribe to a work queue My Work Queues is the list of work queues that the team lead is interested in monitoring. The team lead can subscribe to any manual or automated work queue they have been assigned to monitor. This list displays the number of tasks assigned to each of the listed work queues, allowing the user to understand the current outstanding workload. In Cúram, click the Inbox tab. Workload Management H2 Exp-coll: View team member's workload In Cúram, click the Teams and Workload tab. Click the Shortcuts panel on the left. Click Searches . Click Supervisor User Search . H2 Exp-coll: Add a user working pattern A user's working pattern refers to the specific working hours set for an individual user over a 14-day period. This period starts on a Monday and ends on the 2nd Sunday. The 14-day period will repeat when an end date is not set for a working pattern. Note: The start date of a new working pattern must be a Monday. A working pattern could be added for a user when their working pattern does not align with the organizations default working pattern. For example, if a user works 3 days per week or works part time. This ensures work is assigned limited to their availability. There are several types of working patterns: 14-Day Cycle: Each working pattern covers a 14-day period, which can repeat indefinitely if no end date is set. Standard and Non-Standard Hours: Standard working hours might be set (e.g. 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.). Non-standard hours can be defined for specific days (e.g. a half-day on a Friday from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m.). Non-Working Hours: These can be specified for one or more days and can automatically apply to a full day to indicate a non-working day. Note: A user can have multiple working patterns, but the dates of these patterns cannot overlap. A team lead can manage working pattern for users to ensure the allocation of new tasks based on their availability. The Working Patterns tab allows a team lead to see the user-specific working patterns that have been created. The team lead can select the New menu option to add a new working pattern for the user. In Cúram, click the Teams and Workload tab. Click the Shortcuts panel on the left. Click My Users . Click My Users . The My Users window opens. Click the hyperlinked Name of the user. The user's User Workspace page opens. Click the Working Patterns tab . Click New on the page menu. The New User Working Pattern window opens. Complete the applicable fields for the Working Pattern: Table 9-Fields and Directions of the New User Working Pattern window Field Direction Start Date Mandatory Enter the start date of the user's working pattern. End Date Enter the end of the user's working pattern. Start Time Mandatory Enter the start time of the user's working pattern. End Time Mandatory Enter the end time of the user's working pattern. Click Save . H2 Exp-coll: Update a user working pattern A team lead can make 3 types of updates to a user's working pattern: A team lead can directly update the working pattern to change the start date, end date, start time or end time. A team lead can update certain days in the 14-day cycle to be indicated as non-working days. This would generally include Saturday's, Sunday's and any other day that the user does not work regularly. A team lead can update certain days in the 14-day cycle to have non-standard hours. This could be required if the user has different hours of working on certain days, like half-days. The Edit Non Standard Hours window opens. Update the Type field to Non-Working. Click Save. Note: After clicking Save , the start time and end time will be set to 00:00. To update the working pattern for non-standard days: In Cúram, click the Teams and Workload tab. Click the Shortcuts panel on the left. Click My Users . Click My Users . The My Users window opens. Click the hyperlinked Name of the user. The user's User Workspace page opens. Click the Working Patterns tab . Click the toggle icon ( &gt; ) on the existing working pattern. The existing working pattern expands. Click Edit for the day in the list. The Edit Non Standard Hours window opens. Update the Type field to Non-Standard. Update the Start Time and End Time. Click Save. H2 Exp-coll: Delete a user working pattern A team lead may delete a user working pattern if it has been added in error. In Cúram, click the Teams and Workload tab. H2 Exp-coll: Work queues Updated A work queue is a central repository that organizes, holds, and tracks the tasks that need to be completed within the system. Work queues are used to manage and monitor user-created or system-generated workload. There are 2 types of work queues: automatic work queues and manual work queues. Team members will only be subscribed to manual work queues. Team leads will be subscribed to both automatic and manual work queues to monitor workload, however, team leads will only subscribe team members to manual queues. Automatic work queues are used to hold tasks that can be automatically assigned by the system to users. Manual work queues are used to manage specific tasks that require manual intervention for allocation. A campaign work queue is a work queue created a result of an organization-planned activity or an event. It is organized with the purpose to complete an identified set of tasks by a specific group of staff members. Work queues have been configured specifically for OAS. In addition to automatic and manual work queue configurations, work queues are defined by region and purpose. Each region has a respective automatic and manual work queue Additionally, there are different work queues based on region (region or national), type of workload (migrated from legacy or generated in Cúram), and work queues by business units. Table 23-Types of Work Queues Type of work queue Description Work queue example National work queues Represents a work queue with tasks allocated irrespective of region. One-Workload-Processing One-Workload-PWS-Migrated Regional work queues Represents a work queue with tasks allocated respective of region. OAS-WT-Processing OAS-QC-Processing PWS (legacy) work queues Represents a work queue holding tasks migrated from PWS. OAS-ATL-PWS-Migrated-Automated New task (Cúram-generated) work queues Represents a work queue holding tasks generated by the system (Cúram). OAS-ATL-Processing Work queues by business units Represents a work queue for a specific business unit for their own specific workload. These are part of other types of work queues. OAS-QC-Processing CSB-QC ISB-OAS-NHQ CC-WT-Pensions IO-WT-Processing OAS-Foreign-Direct-Deposit Incarceration-Processing New Error work queue New Represents a work queue for tasks that fail to be automatically sent to the appropriate regional work queue. The failure is due to the appropriate metadata not being captured on the document with a scan location of Virtual . New OAS-INTAKE-ERROR-TASKS H2 Exp-coll: User skill types (virtual skill group – VSG) and descriptions Table 24-User skill types (virtual skill group – VSG) and descriptions Skill Type Title Description OAS-Core-01 Incoming Mail Intake of all incoming mail, and classification of the document types related to OAS program. Registering new clients in Cúram and ensuring attachments are assigned to the correct Person or Case level on the client record. Data capturing of all OAS/GIS/ALW/ALWS applications into the IEG script in Cúram. OAS-Core-02 Core Work activities related to maintenance and client inquiries for the OAS pension and GIS/ALW/ALWS benefits delegated at the CR03 level. OAS-NC-01 OAS/GIS Level 1 Applications and work activities related to the eligibility and entitlement of the OAS pension without periods of residence outside of Canada or periods less than 6 months outside of Canada. Applications and work activities related to the eligibility and entitlement of GIS benefits. OAS-NC-02 ALW/ALWS Level 1 Applications and work activities related to the eligibility and entitlement of ALW/ALWS benefits. OAS-NC-03 Renewal Applications and work activities related to the renewal of GIS/ALW/ALWS benefits. OAS-NC-04 Maintenance Level 1 Work activities related to maintenance and client inquiries for the OAS pension and GIS/ALW/ALWS benefits. OAS-NC-05 Estimated Income Level 1 Statements of Estimated Income and subsequent Recalculations related to the eligibility and entitlement or reconciliation for GIS/ALW/ALWS entitlement. It is only applicable once the documents have been scanned and verified in the Pensions Trusted Digital Repository (PTDR). What you need to know All incoming paper documents (including applications) must be scanned into the PTDR. Once the documents have been scanned into the PTDR, Cúram will upload them and display them in the Attachment tab under Contacts on the Person’s record. This will create one of 2 tasks that must be completed in Cúram: Table 1. Task and description for tasks created once an attachment is uploaded to Cúram Task name Description OAS Intake - Document Classification Match The incoming documentation is matched to an existing client profile in Cúram and the documentation must be reviewed. OAS Intake - Document Classification Non-Match The incoming documentation is not matched to an existing profile in Cúram. A person search must be performed and the documentation must be reviewed. Support clerks must modify the type of document that has been scanned and move it to the correct person or case record in Cúram. This automatically completes the OAS intake task and triggers the creation of a new task that must be completed by a support clerk or processing staff. The following applications will trigger a task for support clerks to add the application in Cúram: Application - ALW 3008 Application - ALW 3033 Application - ALWS 3008 Application - ALWS Blue Application - GIS NB 3025 Application - GIS NB 3025B Application - GIS Take up 3042 Application - GIS Take up 3043 Application - GIS Take up 3044 Application - OAS 3000 Application - OAS 5054 Application - OAS/GIS Integrated 3550 The following applications and documents will trigger a task that must be completed by processing officers : Application – GIS New Business 3018 Application – GIS New Business 3019 Application - OAS Conversion 3045 Application - Statement of Income for ALWS 3007 Application - Statement of Income for the GIS, ALW or ALWS 3026 Application - Statement of Estimated Income 3041 Application - Statement of Estimated Income VAR 3041 All other documents If the information in the application is sufficient, the client can be registered as a Person in Cúram. Any received information must be identified and applied to the Person’s profile. However, if there is insufficient information to create a Person, a Prospect Person is created to store any information that has been captured. Note: Once you add an application to Cúram, there may be a delay of up to 2 minutes before the application is created. Do not add the application again. Attachment destination You must determine why the document was provided and then move it to the appropriate location. If the document is: related to or in support of an application, it must be moved to the Application Case. related to a benefit already in pay, it must be moved to the Integrated Case. related to the individual and not specific to a benefit, keep the attachment on the Person’s record. In cases that support clerks are unsure where to move a document, it can reside on the Person’s record (e.g. paper application received and there is no Application Case) and the document can be moved later by processing staff, if required. Missing or incomplete information on an application When adding an application to Cúram, it may be determined that there is incomplete or missing information. In these cases, do not continue data capturing in the New Application Form wizard. You must edit the task's Skill Type for it to be reassigned to processing staff for them to request the missing information from the applicant. Online applications When a client submits an online application, the evidence types are automatically created in Cúram as the client has provided and identified the applicable information on their online application. This generates an Application Case in Cúram that contains all the information the client provided in their online application. Depending on the circumstances, a task is generated by Cúram that requires a processing officer to verify and activate the evidence to bring the Application Case to the authorization process. No action is required by support clerks for online applications. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do OAS and International Operations In Cúram, click Inbox to view My Open Tasks . What you need to know When a payment that was issued in Cúram is cancelled in the Standard Payment System (SPS), the status automatically changes from Issued to Cancelled , and the status for all instruction line items within the payment change from Processed to Cancelled . This will take 1 to 2 business days. These transactions can be found in the Financials tab at the Person level or in the Product Delivery Case. The SPS communicates both the successful and unsuccessful disbursement of payments back to Cúram, including the reasons for cancellations for traceability purposes. In some instances, you may cancel a payment in SPS before it is redeemed, and this cancellation is communicated to Cúram for further resolution. When a payment is cancelled, you must perform the Check eligibility function in Cúram before applying evidence changes. When a payment is cancelled, Cúram: identifies the non-reversible and reversible deductions: Table 1—Deduction types Deduction Type Employment Insurance Non-reversible CRA Set Off Non-reversible Veterans Affairs Canada Non-reversible Social Assistance Agency Reimbursement Non-reversible Department of Justice Arrears Non-reversible Department of Justice Fees Non-reversible Provincial Voluntary Tax Non-reversible Liability Offset Non-reversible Interest Reversible Penalties Reversible Departmental (Overpayments) Reversible Canada Pension Plan Reversible Non-Resident Tax Conditional OAS Recovery Tax Conditional Federal Voluntary Tax Conditional Note: Conditional deductions are processed as reversible or non-reversible based on the period the deduction was withheld and the date of the cancellation. A reversible deduction can become non-reversible if the cancellation is not in the same calendar year as the initial payment. creates a corresponding Overpayment Case for each non-reversible deduction regardless if the client's eligibility and entitlements during the cancelled payment period was reassessed or not and creates a corresponding deduction against each liability. reverses the reversible deductions and updates (increases) the liability amount back to amount that was reversed. reverses the reversible deductions and updates (decreases) the year-to-date totals by the amount that was reversed. records the cancellation reason for accountability and traceability purposes. updates the status of the payment from Issued to Cancelled . updates the status of any instruction line items from Processed to Cancelled . Updated Once Cúram receives a cancellation notice from the SPS, a task will be created to manage the cancelled payment. There are 2 possible paths you can choose for payment reissuance following a cancelled payment: reissuing payments; or reconciling and reissuing a payment. H2 Exp-coll: Reissuing payments Updated Updated You can reissue a cancelled payment to the original or an alternative nominee. The reissued payment is the same amount as the cancelled payment amount and will be picked up by the system and scheduled to go out for payment issuance as a priority payment. This will be done most often to reissue the payment to a different nominee (e.g. the payment went directly to the client but should have been issued to a third party or can be used to correct incorrect deductions when the payments are NIL or under treshold that do not have non-reversible deductions). Cúram checks if the payment includes any of the following deductions towards: Interest Penalties OAS overpayments Canada Pension Plan (cross program receivables) If any of these deductions are present, Cúram increases the Outstanding Balance Amount by the amount of the reversed deductions. Note: For interest, penalties and OAS overpayments, the deduction will be taken based on the amount withheld at the time of the original issuance, not at the time of reissuance. Where the outstanding debt is now zero, Cúram won't take a deduction. H2 Exp-coll: Reconciling and Reissuing a Payment Updated Updated The Reconcile &amp; Reissue Payment feature is only enabled for Cúram-generated payments, payments with pending Penalty, Interest, or Overpayment liabilities. The Reconcile &amp; Reissue Payment feature is not enabled for cancelled legacy payments and cancelled manual payments. It is used to be able to apply a cancelled payment to an outstanding overpayment, penalty, or interest either as a deduction or an internal reconciliation process. When submitted, the liability amount of the Overpayment, Interest, or Penalty will be reduced. Deductions will only be withheld if any amount is owing after the liability offset deduction and non-reversible deduction overpayments deductions have been applied. If any non-reversible deductions were withheld from the original payment, they will not be deducted a second time. Any reversible deductions (including 'Program Specific Overpayments', Penalties, Interests, CPP deductions) that were part of the original payment may be deducted again with any remaining amount after reconciliation should there still be an outstanding balance. Once you submit reconciling and reissuing a payment, Cúram does the following: It creates a Liability Offset deduction in the amount equal to the sum of the liability offset amounts. When the payment is reissued, Cúram will end-date the liability offset deduction and its status will be changed to Inactive . It reduces the liability amount of the overpayment, interest, or penalty. For overpayments, a write-off is created; for a penalty or interest, the outstanding balance amount is reduced. The reissued payment will be picked-up by the Standard Payment System batch process for further processing if the remaining balance after reconciliation is greater than $1.00. H2 Exp-coll: Payment cancelled after reassessment or the payment included an underpayment If the payment is cancelled after reassessment, you must determine if the cancelled payment should be applied to any existing overpayment. If yes, you must use the Reconcile &amp; Reissue functionality. If no, reissue the payment. H2 Exp-coll: Cancelling Nil or under threshold payments New You can manually cancel a payment record in Cúram if it is within your delegation of authority in the following situations: the payment is created after an Eligibility and Entitlement re-assessment occurs and there is no longer entitlement to that payment; to correct the payment if an incorrect deduction was applied, rather than manually reversing the deduction and paying as a priority payment. The manual cancellation function can be used under the following conditions: The net payment amount is $0.00 ( Nil Payment ); or The net payment is under the $1 threshold ( UT ) and remains in that status, indicating it has not yet been included in a subsequent payment. If you cancel a payment that includes a reversible deduction, you must apply the gross entitlement to the overpayment to void the overpayment to $0.00. If you cancel a payment that included a non-reversible deduction, the amount available to offset should already be reduced by the amount of the non-reversible deduction which would leave an outstanding overpayment equal to the amount of the non-reversible deduction. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: Cancel Nil or under threshold payments New In Cúram, go to client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Financials tab. Click the Transactions tab in the page group navigation bar on the left. The Transactions page opens. A list of payments can be viewed here. View the status of each payment under Status in the context panel box. Click the ( &gt; ) toggle icon next to the payment with a status of Nil Payment or UT to view the deduction source and if the deduction is a non-reversible or reversible deduction. Note: If a payment falls below the minimum threshold of $1.00, Cúram will not issue it immediately. If subsequent payments are made and the combined total exceeds the $1.00 threshold, Cúram will automatically issue the previously withheld underpayment. Once this occurs, you can no longer manually cancel the payment; you must follow the regular cancellation process. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu to the right of the payment to be cancelled and select Cancel Payment . The Cancel Payment window opens. Select Issued in error from the Reason drop-down menu. Enter the comments in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Save . The payment is now cancelled. H2 Exp-coll: Reissue payments In Cúram, go to client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Financials tab. Click the Transactions tab in the page group navigation bar on the left. The Transactions page opens. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu to the right of the payment to be reissued and select Reissue . The Reissue Payment window opens. Do one of the following: Check the Reissue to the Original Nominee checkbox to issue the payment to the same nominee who received original payment; or Select a name from the Reissue to Another Nominee drop-down menu to issue the payment to a nominee on the Product Delivery Case who did not receive the original payment. Click Reissue . H2 Exp-coll: Reconcile and reissue a cancelled payment In Cúram, go to client's profile. Refer to Search for a Person in Cúram (Action) . Click the Financials tab. Click the Transactions tab in the page group navigation bar on the left. The Transactions page opens. Click the 3-dots ( … ) action menu to the right of the payment to be reissued and select Reconcile and Reissue . The Reconcile &amp; Reissue Payment window opens showing the reissue payment and liability details. Do one of the following: Select the Reissue to the Original Nominee checkbox to issue the payment to the same nominee who received original payment; or Select a name from the Reissue to Another Nominee drop-down menu to issue the payment to a nominee on the Product Delivery Case who did not receive the original payment. Enter the appropriate amount in the Offset Amount field. Refer to Liability Offset—Create, Complete and Delete in Cúram (Action) . The offset amount cannot be more than the outstanding amount of the liability record. The total offset amount cannot exceed the difference between the payment amount and the non-reversible deduction amount. You must enter an Offset Amount for at least one Liability record. Click Reconcile &amp; Reissue . Top tab: References There is no reference material. (KA-01423 Snippet 14.0 content. Do not modify or delete.)</content></document><document><reference>https://kmt-ogc.service.gc.ca/en/knowledgebase/article-latest?pid=KA-05513&amp;cid=CAT-01959</reference><title>Maintain Social Security Agreement Country Information, Contacts and Addresses (Action)</title><video_link>[-1]</video_link><video_name>['placeholder']</video_name><walkme_flow_id>[-1]</walkme_flow_id><walkme_flow_name>['placeholder']</walkme_flow_name><content>Overview Summary This procedure provides you with the steps to add, edit and view Social Security Agreement (SSA) country information, contacts and addresses for countries with which Canada has an active International Social Security Agreement (ISSA). What you need to know PSCD creates interest automatically on liabilities when penalties are imposed on a client. When this happens, PSCD issues a report requiring you to create or modify an interest record on a client's penalty liability or overpayment case. Interest is a liability owed by a client to the Department. It is a separate liability from a penalty liability or overpayment that the interest is owed on. Interest can only be charged if a penalty is imposed, even if the amount imposed is 0. The amount of interest charged will be based on many factors including the collection status, the amount of the penalty and/or any associated overpayments. Liabilities, including interest records, can only be deleted in the pre-payment period which occurs before gross to net has been calculated. Top tab: Step by Step What you need to do H2 Exp-coll: Create an interest record from a Public Sector Collections and Disbursements report In Cúram, go to the person's profile. Liability Type Mandatory Select Interest - OAS or Interest – OAS Non-Beneficiary from the Liability Type drop-down menu. Liability Amount Mandatory Enter the liability amount. Enter the comment in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Next . Enter the information in the Select Benefit Type section as follows: Table 2—Fields and Directions under the Select Benefit Type section Field Direction Product Delivery Cases Mandatory Check the box for the product delivery case. Interest Details Mandatory Click the radio button for the penalty liability or overpayment case this interest is against. Click Save . The interest appears as a liability in the Outstanding Balance table. Enter comments in the Comments field, if applicable. Click Save . The interest is now modified in the Outstanding Balance table. The Department uses special caution(s) to alert staff of the issues and concerns. A red exclamation mark in the top-left of the Profile Home Screen identifies a person with a special caution. Special cautions do not stop processing on a client account. All processes currently in place with the client should proceed while special cautions are present on a client account. A special caution indicates the Department needs to pay attention to the account to ensure correct business processes are followed. A client can have more than one special caution applied to their profile. For example, if the client has a risk of inaccurate migrated data and their whereabouts are unknown. Special cautions may be added in the following instances: Special Caution Type Description Whereabouts Unknown An Employment and Social Development Canada Department representative can create a Whereabouts Unknown special caution when the client cannot be located. Based on the established procedures, once certain duration has elapsed and the client still cannot be located, the client may be referred to the Integrity Services Branch (ISB) for investigation and another special caution can be created to capture Under Investigation with ISB . If the ISB is not able to locate the client, you must leave the flag on the account even after the investigation has been concluded. Under Appeal A Department representative can create an Under Appeal special caution to indicate that the client has submitted an appeal to Social Security Tribunal (SST). Under Reconsideration A Department representative can create an Under Reconsideration special caution to indicate that a paper-based Request for Reconsideration document was uploaded for a client. Additional Security Criteria When the ISB has identified that a specific client requires additional security criteria for authentication, an Additional Security Criteria flag can be set and maintained for the Client. Risk of Inaccurate Migrated Data The migration process has identified that some clients may have inaccurate data migrated from the pay pattern file. Under Investigation with ISB A Department representative has referred the client to the ISB for investigation and captures the flag for the client. Note: Specific pay pattern error codes will indicate that it is necessary to apply a special caution of the type Risk of Inaccurate Migrated Data . These error codes do not exist in Cúram currently. Note: Do not add a special caution flag if the account has Reconsideration In Progress written in red in the context panel. The Under Consideration special caution flag is only necessary when a paper-based request for reconsideration has been uploaded for a client, but the request for reconsideration has not yet been added to the client account. The Under Reconsideration special caution flag must be removed as soon as the request for reconsideration has been added to the account. Refer to Manage Requests for Reconsideration in Cúram (Action) . Special cautions should be removed in the following situations: The Department has located a client whose location was previously not known. The ISB has concluded their investigation. The Under ISB Investigation flag can only be removed by a SCBO and only after the adjustments have been applied. The client's appeal to the SST has been finalized. All paper-based reconsideration documents for the client have been captured in Cúram and all the client's reconsideration requests have been resolved. The ISB has determined that the additional security criteria is no longer required on the client's account. Additional security criteria can be added by other channels as well in addition to ISB. All inaccurate migrated data previously identified in the client's record has been resolved. All special cautions that have been removed will be display in the Previous tab of the Special Cautions tab. Note: Only delete a special caution on a person record in one of the following situations: The special caution is placed in the wrong record. The wrong type of special caution was placed in the record. The special caution was placed with the wrong date. In any of these situations, the special caution should subsequently be added to the correct account, with the correct type and date. What you need to know In Cúram, foreign creditable periods are entered as either foreign contribution period or foreign residence period evidence on a Foreign Engagement Case. The number of entries you can make is unlimited and gaps are allowable between creditable periods. Foreign creditable periods are added to the Canadian residence calculated from the Integrated Case to help the client meet the minimum Canadian residence requirements to receive OAS benefits. OAS pension entitlement is still calculated based on actual years of Canadian residence. Refer to Validate Residence (Scenario) for additional information. If a Canadian residence period in the Application Case overlaps with a foreign residence period on the FEC, an issue will be raised on the Evidence Dashboard . If a Canadian residence period in the Integrated Case or a Foreign residence period on the FEC is modified, and an overlap is created, a warning message is displayed. This must be resolved before the evidence can be activated. Refer to Resolve Issues for Foreign Contribution and Canadian Residence Periods in Cúram (Action) . If exact dates are not available, foreign periods must be recorded in unstructured foreign contribution period or unstructured foreign residence period evidence. These evidences are used to capture a client's description of their foreign creditable periods that are received without start and end dates. These evidences are not used by Cúram in determining eligibility or entitlement. If an application must be adjudicated manually for OAS Benefits with unstructured creditable periods, overrides must be leveraged.
